B000002C25|5.0|More and more, I begin to see Oasis as one of the only bands, well, ever, that brings a consistently optimistic message. It's not every day you hear lyrics like: \\"All around the world / you gotta spread the word / tell em what you heard / you know it's gonna be okay.\\" <br /> <br />Mind you, this isn't _why_ the album is good. It's good because it's unique and well-executed, and the songs are great. Overall, it might not be as great a musical achievement as Def-Mab or Morning Glory, but it's a great listen - and the kind of thing that has a tendancy to become a part of one's life. <br /> <br />Be Here Now is over seventy minutes long, with only two real songs clocking in at under four minutes. The long format is usually better suited to either techno or classical, so it's interested to see it attempted here with (admittedly) fairly standard rock, stretching the limites of the traditional verse-chorus-verse-chorus-fade. A few songs drag, but most only grow more powerful the longer they run. They demand to be taken seriously, not as just as music, but as statements on life. In a way, the album is very high-concept. <br /> <br />The definite winners are Stand By Me, and the two long kickers D'You Know What I Mean? and Be Here Now. All Around the World may be too sappy for a few, but I found it heartfelt. After its amazing seven minutes, though, the equally long and upbeat It's Getting Better (Man!) seems almost unncessary, although it's a good song in its own right. Finally you have a two-minute orchestral reprise of All Around, sampling the 1812 overture. If you've been following the album, it's the perfect closer, so deliriously over-the-top it make you laugh and smile at the same time. If you haven't, it probably pushes it hopelessly into the territory of kitsch. <br /> <br />So while it may not be for everyone, Be Here Now is certainly a worthy addition to Oasis' catalogue and a daring follow-up to Morning Glory. Recommended. <br /> <br />

Nathan 'Diamond Dog' Jones (Ving Rhames), a black militant inside for murder. Billy Bedlam (Nick Chinlund), inside for killing his cheating wife's family and dog. Pinball Parker (Dave Chapelle), a pimp and drug-dealer. Swamp Thing (MC Gainey) a pilot who knows a few things about a good hijack. And finally Garland Green AKA The Marietta Mangler (Steve Buscemi) a serial killer in for killing a zillion people and crossing 2 state borders wearing a girls head as a hat.<br /><br />As you can tell, with such a eclectic bunch of psychos on board it's only a matter of seconds before all hell breaks loose. As soon as the plane is in the air the cons have taken over, restrained or killed the guards and have changed the destination from prison to South America.<br /><br />Poe, being the good-hearted sort of chap that he is, doesn't rat out as his best pal needs his insulin shot and no one else will help. It's up to Poe to sneakily round up the baddies until US Marshall Larkin (John Cusack) and the cavalry can get there. Easier said than done, as double-crosses, suspicious cons and incompetent authority foul everything up. The result is action overload as the film blazes through to it's anarchic, devastating climax upon another anarchic, devastating climax. At the end you'll be left breathless and your senses stinging with over-stimulation. Con Air is everything an action film should be.<br /><br />Steve Buscemi steals the whole show. His deadpan, bug-eyed and dare I say 'innocent' portrayal of a deranged killer is the centrepiece of the whole film. The scene where he sings with a little girl (and continues later on) will either freak you out or steal your heart. And the ending is the best you could hope for.<br /><br />Mark Mancina and Trevor Rabin provide a loud, blaring score of thrash-metal and acoustic guitars with the usual Media Ventures flare. It's brilliant stuff and I suggest you hunt down the (sadly incomplete) score CD. And this really did deserve the Best Original Song award over that pansy Titanic one.<br /><br />Superior to both The Rock and Face/Off, Con Air is Nic Cage at his (worst) best as an action hero and Bruckheimer at his best as an action producer. See it, for the love of God, see it.<br /><br />However, the Region 1 DVD is quite crap with no extras and a rubbish 2.35:1 non-anamorhic picture. The Region 2 DVD is anamorphic, with nice motion menus, trailers and some brief featurettes. Get that version if you can.ess and your senses stinging with over-stimulation. Never happened before and will never happen again, but I just couldn't bring myself to leave.  <br /> <br />So, basically, what was everyone expecting?  An award winning Titanic? They eat.... very... tiny... bits.... at a time. So, all i kept thinking was, this is the worst cat i've ever seen. try harder.  <br /> <br />cute movie though.

B000A59PMO|5.0|Lost and Desperate Housewives got all the hype last season. They were supposed to be the pendulum swing away from Reality programming and back to quality hour long scripted drama. But the outstanding freshman drama of 2004-2005 was Veronica Mars.  <br /> <br />Desperate Housewives descended into soap opera. Lost failed to deliver a plot to go along with its pretty and talented cast. Veronica Mars on UPN, on the other hand, proceeded to show the big boy networks how it is done.  <br /> <br />Veronica Mars is a well scripted,  phenomenally acted show that rewarded its viewers with a complete story arc that answered all questions posed in the pilot.  <br /> <br />The cast is mostly young unknowns who proved their talent and ability to engage the audience with an engrossing storyline. The show is smart, funny, tragic, romantic and film noir all rolled into one pleasing confection. <br />  <br />The incredibly talented Kristen Bell (Showtime's Reefer Madness) stars as Veronica Mars. She is a high school student who has lost everything. Her rich boyfriend broke up with her with no explanation. Her best friend was murdered. Veronica's  sheriff father lost his job in the ensuing investigation, while Veronica lost her social status as a result. Her mother abandoned the family. Veronica was drugged and raped.  <br /> <br />In order to make ends meet her father becomes a private investigator and Veronica works in his office after school  All this is laid out in the pilot.  <br /> <br />Kristen makes you believe this character with every frame in which she appears.  <br /> <br />Rob Thomas, a former teacher and creator of the too quickly cancelled Cupid, is the mind behind Veronica Mars. He knows today's high school students and presents them in a fairly matter of fact fashion.  <br /> <br />Kids drink. They do stupid things. There are consequences. And they are cruel to outsiders and Veronica is an outsider. Just not as much as she likes to think. She manages to make quite afew friends along the way, solving cases for fellow students who need her help, as well as helping her dad with his cases.  <br /> <br />Unlike the claustrophobic sets of many high school shows where characters rarely interact with anyone outside the main cast except for the MOTW plot, classmates you meet in early episodes here actually reappear in later episodes and even with limited screen time their stories seem as rich as the main characters stories.  <br /> <br />Veronica is not perfect or always right. She does not give self-righteous speeches. She is all about Old Testament 'eye for an eye\\" vengeance. She is complicated. <br /> <br />She has a loving relationship with her father. A sweetly supportive platonic best friend Wallace. Weevil is the leader of the local motorcyle gang as well as Veronica's muscle when she needs a favor. Duncan is the ex-boyfriend with secrets to hide. And Logan, played by the excellent Jason Dohring, is the snarky rich kid that makes her heart beat faster even when she hates herself for it.  <br /> <br />Veronica, in short, is a self admitted \\"trainwreck\\". And watching her sort out the mysteries in her life while sorting out her place in Neptune high school is a pure pleasure.  <br /> <br />Thankfully the DVD's will be out in October. Unfortunately the second season of Veronica Mars starts Wednesdays on UPN in September. Try to catch the show in reruns to be up to speed for the second season of this wonderful show!  <br /> <br />
B00062ZE3U|5.0|For a \\"Silent Force\\", it sure does pack one hell of a punch. I think this CD is amazing in several ways... Reading over some of the reviews, some accuse Within Temptation of becoming mainstream, or compare Sharon den Adel to Evanescene's Amy Lee. Wrong. Metal can't be mainstream, unless you're Metallica, or System of a Down. People will disagree with me on this, but I only feel this way due to the exposure of the band. As for American exposure? None that I know of... But I just wanted to clear up that Amy Lee is NOT Sharon den Adel, and will never be anywhere close. Within Temptation is NOT Evanescence. It's like comparing Nightwish to Evanescence... Not even of the same genre, therefore comparing is pointless. Anyway, my rating is as follows...<br /><br />1. Intro - 5/5 - Just a brief entry into the CD. Instrumental flutterings that head into a sort of choral sound, not sure if it's just vocalizing, or if they're actually singing something. Then, Sharon den Adel, with her fantastic and non-Amy Lee voice (because her register is much higher), vocalizes for a bit, then transitions into the next track.<br /><br />2. See Who I Am - 6/5 - This is a very strong track. Starting heavy, heads into a mellow verse with the angelic voice. Then, the bridge becomes heavy, and the chorus becomes heavier, with a very distinct heavy balance. Repeat to end.<br /><br />3. Jillian (I'd Give My Heart) - 6/5 - The song starts out slow, which kind of bothers me, because it takes 30 seconds to reach it's point. However, when it finally hits, you know the wait is worth it. The chorus is my favorite part of the song. There are ever-present \\"Ah-ah\\"'s in the background, and I think that adds a little something. With Sharon den Adel's high register, this song is well worth it.<br /><br />4. Stand My Ground - 6/5 - This is where I can see that someone would accuse Within Temptation of becoming mainstream. This song could have very easily became popular in the US (similar to Evanescence's \\"Bring Me To Life\\") because it's not extremely heavy, and not too slow. But considering the genre (whatever it may be), I don't see much happening with them in the US, yet. But this is a very good song.<br /><br />5. Pale - 4/5 - This is a very slow song. It's still a good song (if you pay attention to the lyrics). Her voice soars in the chorus, she lets you know she can belt it out. Some decent drum sounds in the song into the second verse. A slow song with powerful vocals, as always.<br /><br />6. Forsaken - 5/5 - I didn't like this song much at first, it had to grow on me. I liked the guitars, and the heaviness, but her voice just didn't seem to work with the melody for some reason. But repetitive listening of the awesome CD made me think otherwise. Similar background vocals that were in \\"Jillian (I'd Give My Heart)\\" were also present in this song, it really clings well to the music. Towards the end of the song, it seems like it's going to end, but it picks back up and takes the song to the end the right way. (Right meaning how it SHOULD be done) :-)<br /><br />7. Angels - 4/5 - This song is definitely one of those misleading types. It starts out nice, angelic (as the title implies), and the takes a 180 degree turn into a completely different angle. I call it an anger song, because the words seem to be something someone would say to an ex. I don't want to ruin the surprise for any of you, you should just buy the CD and listen.<br /><br />8. Memories - 4/5 - This is the first song on the CD that I heard. I thought, \\"Hey, this sounds kind of like the old Within Temptation stuff...\\" (old meaning \\"Mother Earth\\" etc.) But then I heard the rest of the album and realized they were far from the same. They have changed, and I feel for the better. This song is very slow at first, but moves into a more upbeat pace, but leaves the same thought. Not my favorite, but still a sweet song.<br /><br />9. Aquarius - 7/5 - This song was my first love on the album. I can't really describewhy... But whatever they did in this song just blows me away. It's probably the chorus... or mostway through the song when she vocalizes into a heavier, higher octave chorus in preparations for the finale of the song. I don't know an Aquarius... But then again, I assume she's talking about some kind of water god... Not the zodiac sign (due to the words of the song).<br /><br />10. It's The Fear - 3/5 - I don't really like this song. The string of words in the song that I do like, however, are, \\"...Because my fate, is horror and doom...\\" Even so, I don't think the words fit this particular song... When she says, \\"horror and doom\\" ... The music surrounding her does not suggest that. It's probably just my picky taste.<br /><br />11. Somewhere - 3/5 - This is the only other song on the CD I don't really like. It's slow, which is ok, and the words actually match the music in this one... I don't know, like \\"It's The Fear\\", it just never grew on me.<br /><br />12. A Dangerous Mind - 10/5 - In my opinion, this is the best track on the album. Everything's amazing... The intro, the verses, the chorus, the lyrics. It's just a masterpiece. I don't know what else to say about it really... The only word I can think of is, \\"Perfect\\". \\"I just have to know... While I still have time... Do I have to run? Or hide?! Away... From you?!?!\\"<br /><br />13. Swan Song - 6/5 - Swan song? Better not be. Beautiful song, no complaints... Nothing to really describe... Just another great song.<br /><br />This force is far from silent. Maybe Within Temptation planned it like that. I hope this helps anyone, and that it clears up the Within Temptation/Evanescence confusion.t really describe why... But whatever they did in this song just blows me away. It's probably the chorus... or mostway through the song when she vocalizes into a heavier, higher octave chorus in preparations for the finale of the song. I don't know an Aquarius... But then again, I assume she's talking about some kind of water god... Not the zodiac sign (due to the words of the song). <br /> <br />10. It's The Fear - 3/5 - I don't really like this song. When she says, \\"horror and doom\\" ... The music surrounding her does not suggest that. It's probably just my picky taste. <br /> <br />11. 0446607274|5.0|Published in 1998/99, this is Connelly's sixth Harry Bosch story; by now he has twice that many novels, not all in the Bosch set.  \\"Flight\\" is another fine entry starring the intellectual, somewhat reclusive LAPD homicide detective, although in this one Bosch is still married to (gambling addict) Eleanor, the cause of much anxiety as a sub-plot to this tough yarn.  Things get rolling when Bosch is called out late at night -- out of turn and out of territory -- when a black lawyer specializing in suing the LAPD turns up dead on an inclined railway just days before a high profile case against the cops goes to court.  Various police brass and Internal Affairs are at the scene, and all are worried about another round of Rodney King-type riots.  As the teams pursue various issues, the complex plot shifts from one suspect to another, most of whom are fellow men in blue; but Bosch doggedly chases all the clues despite the chiefs wanting this one over and done fast, with Bosch's ex-pard Sheehan on a platter as the bad guy.  The role of a pedophile web site and a young girl's wealthy parents add dark tension to matters as well.  In several twists near the incredibly suspenseful ending, the blame shifts back and forth among perps as fast as one can keep the pages turning!  And the final ironic dispensation of justice is just that.<br /><br />We've read enough of Connelly's work now to rate him very highly in this genre.  He crafts terrific, complicated, and intriguing plots that are difficult to scope out till quite near the very end.  While his leading men and ladies are hardly perfect, we soon care about them; we feel their pain and frustration with not only the quirks of the case at hand, but even just the same life stuff with which we readers have to contend!  His fan base only grows side by side with his booklist.  Enjoy!

Willy Wonka, inventor of dozens of candy concoctions, puts five Golden Tickets into the wrappers of his candy and sends them to different corners of the world. The tickets eventually land in the hands of the fat chocolate addict Augustus Gloop, spoiled brat Veruca Salt, gum chewing maniac Violet Beauregard, the violent video gamer Mike Teevee, and of course, the hero of the story, the sweet, innocent, and ordinary boy Charlie Bucket. You will love Freddie Highmore as Bucket. He's so perfect, so adorable, and little Charlie knows exactly what the most important thing in life is-- family family family.  <br /> <br />So instead of bogging this review down with more plot points that you should probably already know, I'll just skip to what makes this such a great film. Tim Burton! He set out to make a version that was more like the book. Well he succeeded plus some! This is not at all a re-make of that fluffy 70s movie. The style, the sound, the characters are all wonderfully different. There's more SUBSTANCE, especially with Wonka's character. And the only singing comes from the Oompa Loompas. Thank God. His style, from the design of the candy room to the crookedness of Charlie's house, is more what I had in mind when Iread the book. One of the toughest things for me to overcome while watching this movie was the Oompa Loompas. Forget the orange faces and green hair. Yes, it's hard to do because the image is stamped on all our brains, but you have to in order to see this movie. <br /> <br />Great movie. Would see it again. Very sweet and, well, sensitive. Sends out a positive message to kids and will hopefully keep some away from greediness and video games... at least for a while. Definitely check it out. B00009P1O2|5.0|I own both this disc and the \\"On Fire at the Bowl\\" DVD. This is by far my favorite. Everything is done right and to perfection here. There is a majesty in the filming and editing that is missing in the other performance. Maybe it's the energy of this awesome Wembley crowd. Shot just before sunset, the transition to night time is magical and Freddie commands! He is loved by and connected to the crowd like very few performers. The sound is stellar, Brian is in great form, the harmonies are spot on, it is incredible to realize this wall of great sound is coming mostly from a trio. Of the 28 songs on this DVD there are only 8 that are on the \\"On Fire..\\" disc, making this practically a whole different show. I prefer the selections on this Wembley performance and although some reviewers claim the performance on the \\"On Fire..\\" disc was better, I do not agree. The combination of song selection, multi camera filming, sound quality, and a second disc of extras make this the preferred choice for me. An absolute must have for ANY fan of classic rock.

B00005JNSK|4.0|The first third of this movie, where you meet poor little Charlie Bucket and his family in their dilipidated home, where they are so poor that his grandparents sleep in one bed by the fire, head to toe, is so nearly perfect and straight from the novel by Roald Dahl that I actually got tense as Charlie would open each candy bar and still not find that golden ticket. The disgusting children around the world finding those tickets were spot-on as well, including the best update whatsover in the movie, where Mike Teavee, who in the book dresses as a cowboy and shoots his toy gun at the TV screen, is translated into an expert videogamer playing a Quake-like game while being interviewed.<br /><br />Of course, perfection when it comes to translating a movie from book to screen is something rarely achieved, and I should be grateful for even that first third. Because as soon as Willy Wonka greets the children, the flaw in this movie becomes all-too-readily apparent: Tim Burton repeats the mistake he made in the first Batman film by putting a famous actor in the lead role who doesn't so much play the role as he plays himself playing the role. In Batman, it was Jack Nicholson who couldn't see the movie because of his own greasepaint; here, it's Johnny Depp, who looks the part, but plays it with more ticks than Big Ben. Sometimes, as in Nicholson's Joker, it's funny--but the problem is that it is distracting from the story, and the story should be king.<br /><br />After his introduction, and we start the actual tour of the factory where the children show their true colors, we get back to the story, but every once and awhile Burton highlights Wonka again, with the addition of flashbacks to Wonka's own childhood that are not from the book and were totally unnecessary to the plot.<br /><br />On the plus side, Burton uses Dahl's lyrics for the songs that the Oompa Loompas sing about the bad children. Unfortunately, the songs are so overproduced in both sound (a typically Danny Elfman-type error with movie music--it was fine when he was in a rock band, but in a movie, you only get once chance to hear the lyrics and having the music overwhelm them defeats the purpose of having lyrics) and visuals (the Oompa Loompas are one man, digitally reproduced, and in the dance numbers this becomes so apparant that instead of enjoying the visuals, you are distracted by noticing the filmmaking).<br /><br />All in all, I liked the movie, for when Burton gets it right, such as when the squirrels decide the Veruca Salt is a very bad nut, it captures the book perfectly. I'm just saddened that Burton (or the studio?) felt that they had to insert differences from the book. Danny deVito's Matilda remains the best adaptation of Dahl from book to screen, and that's because he didn't waver from the book, in large part due to his children threatening him that doing so would make them very, very mad. I guess Burton didn't have that type of editor.Elfman-type error with movie music--it was fine when he was in a rock band, but in a movie, you only get once chance to hear the lyrics and having the music overwhelm them defeats the purpose of having lyrics) and visuals (the Oompa Loompas are one man, digitally reproduced, and in the dance numbers this becomes so apparant that instead of enjoying the visuals, you are distracted by noticing the filmmaking). <br /> <br />All in all, I liked the movie, for when Burton gets it right, such as when the squirrels decide the Veruca Salt is a very bad nut, it captures the book perfectly. I'm just saddened that Burton (or the studio?) felt that they had to insert differences from the book. Danny deVito's Matilda remains the best adaptation of Dahl from book to screen, and that's because he didn't waver from the book, in large part due to his children threatening him that doing so would make them very, very mad. I guess Burton didn't have that type of editor.
B000002N2P|5.0|Get your Green Day facts straight, people! <br /> <br />To all the ignorant (and uninitiated) Green Day fans here (and there seem to be many): Be careful when you say \\"Have a green day\\", because you're inviting someone to go out with you and get blitzed off pot for the entire day. So, if you say that to someone, be sure to have a stash to share. The term \\"Green Day\\" was (and still is) Bay Area slang for laying around all day and doing nothing but smoking pot. Billie and Mike were so fond of weed that they changed their name from Sweet Children to Green Day as an ode to their love of the reefer. <br /> <br />Anyway... <br />In 1987, the band released a four-song Sweet Children EP on Skene Records. At this point, they weren't known as Green Day yet. The first EP the band released under the name of \\"Green Day\\" was 1,000 Hours (which came out in late 1988). The 39/Smooth EP came out in 1990 (months apart from the Slappy EP). 39/Smooth was not a f*cking LP.  As stated by a previous reviewer, Kerplunk WAS in fact Green Day's first LP (long-playing record). Unlike later CD pressings, the original vinyl LP does not contain the Sweet Children bonus tracks from the '87 EP.  <br /> <br />LPs are full-length albums, while EPs are shorter, and contain less than a full album.  <br /> <br />Okay, I'm out of breath.
B00006JJ1O|5.0|The debut album by t.A.T.u. is a very unique album. It cannot be branded into any one genre of music, and it is certainly a far cry from today's mainstream music disaster. This album describes the relationships of two teenage girls in love. This may seem controversial to many people, but the thought-provoking lyrics and instense music really help shape them into a unique and different band. Some songs, such as Not Gonna Get Us, All The Things She said, and Clowns, have pounding beats and meaningful lyrics. Others such as 30 Minutes and Stars show you the more mellower side of t.A.T.u. Every song describes different things young lesbians must go through. Thoughts of running away to be together (Not Gonna Get Us, All The Things She Said), being accepted by other people for who they are (How Soon Is Now?, Clowns), or showing love to one another (Show Me Love, Stars) are all common themes in this album. The only song that does not bare a lesbian image is Malchik Gay, and it still has a theme dealing with homosexuality. Malchik Gay translates into \\"Gay Boy\\" and it talks about a girl falling for a gay boy. If I had to classify this album into a genre, i would call it dancepop. For those of you who think t.A.T.u. have faded into oblivion, don't worry, their english sophomore release, \\"Dangerous and Moving\\", will be released in America October 18th and their russian sophomore release, \\"Lyudi-Invalidi (Invalid People)\\" will be released October 17th. Their first single off of that album, \\"All About Us\\" will hit radios September 1st. I reccommend buying this album. You will not be disappointed.

1591840562|5.0|If you are interested in starting a business and want to get a lay of the land, get best practices, buy this book now.  <br /> <br />Kawasaki uses his past at Apple and his experience as a successful venture capitalist to net out what really is important in starting a new business.  <br /> <br />The key insights from this book are: <br /> <br />- Entrepreneurs need to focus on 5 things - Make Meaning (are you doing to save the world, help the under-privileged), make Mantra (don't go for mission statements, but catching one-worders), get going, define your business models, and weave a MAT (milestones, assumptions and tasks) <br />- Positioning: Be crystal clear in articulating what do you do to be successful in positioning your product/service <br />- Pitching: 10-20-30, 10 slides, 20 minutes, 30 size font. Get off to a fast start and explain what you do in 1-minute and use the remaining 20 minutes to explain it further and then open it up for questions <br />- Business Plans: 10 pages, Title, Problem, Solution, Biz Model, Secret Sauce, Marketing and Sales, Competition, Mgmt team, Financials, and Current status <br />- Focus on being self-sustaining for 2-3 years <br />- Build a strong network by connecting through your passions (cars, kids, dogs, computers...) <br />- Engage people by telling them something that is interesting yet entertaining <br />- Evangelism is a key approach to brand your products <br />- Always earn the right goodwill by helping people, doing what's right and paying back society <br /> <br />Guy's approach in writing this book is focused on potential entrepreneurs like you and me rather than the usual academic mumbo-jumbo on starting a business. He has easy down-to-earth, \\"been there, done that\\" style without sounding too condescending, like the rest of his ilk at Silicon Valley venture capitalists, are prone to.  <br /> <br />This book has less than 200 pages and is definitely worth a read. <br /> <br />Your starting to become an entrepreneur, <br />Fred \\"Garage\\" Sanford <br />

B0002FR07O|5.0|I bought the Signify album a couple years ago and loved it.  Just recently I was in the store and noticed that the reissue was packaged with an entire second album of demo and unreleased material!  That was enough incentive for me to buy this double album, and I was glad I did! <br /> <br />If you have never heard Signify in the first place, I can only say that it is a fantastic album and you won't regret buying it.  If you need more convincing, just look at the reviews for the original Signify album, I don't want to get into that here. <br /> <br />This album is a remastered version of the original.  To be honest the album didn't especially need a remaster.  This version does sound a bit cleaner and has a stronger bass sound, but I haven't compared the two side by side and I don't notice any major differences.   <br /> <br />The real prize here is the second disc, an album called \\"Insignificance\\" that was only available through the PT information service back in 97.  Although it's comprised of b-sides and demos, \\"Insignificance\\" is a better album than most bands would record at all, and a real treat for die hard PT fans who didn't get to hear it the first time around. <br /> <br />\\"Wake as Gun I\\" is just a solid PT song in the vein of the other non-instrumental tracks on Signify, perhaps not as unique as the ones that made the album but still a great track. <br /> <br />\\"Hallogallo\\" features the same tune as the opening of the track \\"Signify,\\" but it is played without the distortion and the feel of the song is much softer. <br /> <br />\\"Signify\\" is close to the album version, but isn't quite as aggressive and actually has some vocals towards the end!   <br /> <br />\\"Waiting\\" is the same as the album version, except not as developed as far as the background and electronics of the track, and the lead and other guitar fills are arranged differently.  Hearing this formative version really makes you appreciate the beautiful phrasing of the guitar leads in the final version. <br /> <br />\\"Smiling not Smiling\\" is another song like \\"Wake as Gun\\" that didn't make the album, but is definitely a good inclusion on this one. <br /> <br />\\"Wake as Gun II\\" begins basically the same as \\"Wake as Gun I\\" but disintegrates into ambience and guitar noise.  Interesting track. <br /> <br />\\"Neural Rust\\" is a very cool instrumental track, but much more upbeat sounding than \\"Signify\\".  Keen PT fans will expect this to be an early version of \\"Every Home is Wired,\\" but in fact the songs have no relation.  I nterestingly enough the opening drumbeat is the same one used to open \\"Dark Matter\\". <br /> <br />\\"Dark Origins\\" is exactly what it sounds like it would be.  The song starts with the beginning of \\"Dark Matter\\" and then continues with that basic pattern and expands it into a great instrumental track, I guess in the same manner that \\"Waiting phase two\\" took the bassline from \\"Waiting\\" and expanded on it.   <br /> <br />\\"Sever Tomorrow\\" is basically the same as \\"Sever,\\" but I think the revised title was a good choice. <br /> <br />\\"Nine Cats- acoustic version\\" is exactly that, an acoustic version of the \\"On the Sunday of Life\\" classic.   <br /> <br />If you never had Signify, this is a great time to pick it up.  IF you already know how great the album is...what are you waiting for?  This is more than worth the purchase.
B0000TB01Y|5.0|This past Christmas, a friend with a bit of foresight gave me this recording, telling me that I couldn't be a \\"true theater kid\\" until I listened to it. Being at the time more into Blink-182 than Norbert Leo Butz, I doubted her words, but, upon listening to this album... and then Rent... and Avenue Q... and The Last Five Years, and so on, I can say that Wicked is without a doubt one of the best musicals I know of, due majorly to its cast members but also the music itself's quality. <br /> <br />If you're looking for subtlety, Wicked is not for you. But if you want overblown, soaring, bombastic SHOW TUNES, then buy it right now. There's a reason that a musical is currently in Amazon's top 20 sellers, and that is its pop sensibility, which makes the musical a true standout. <br /> <br />Looking at specific songs, there are the obvious standouts. My personal favorite, the hopeful and exuberant \\"The Wizard and I,\\" the sweet, if unoriginal, \\"As Long As You're Mine,\\" and of course the simply astonishing Act I finale, the indescribable \\"Defying Gravity.\\" Whenever I feel like slamming doors, jumping up and down on my bed and screaming along with a \\"who needs you anyway?\\" song, I always head straight for \\"Defying Gravity.\\"  <br /> <br />And so it is an obvious conclusion to reach that the star of the show is the incomparable Idina Menzel. Surrounded by a cast of amazing talent, she still makes herself stand out. Costar Kristen Chenoweth is operatic, utterly convincing, and devestatingly hilarious, and Norbert Leo Butz as the love interest is used to great, if not enough, effect, in \\"Dancing Through Life\\" and the aforementioned \\"As Long As You're Mine.\\" But Menzel's powerful and unique voice destroys all competition for the spotlight. Her husky pipes turn what would be a good recording into a stellar one. Built on the solid foundation of a plot, which is wholly unlike Gregory Maguire's also excellent book of the same name, the songs are allowed to soar into the stratosphere in a musical that redefines BIG. A must-buy, in my opinion, if only because of Ms. Menzel's amazing talent.

B0006L16N8|4.0|Being a huge Coldplay fan, I was very excited for X&Y, and songs like the lead-off single, \\"Speed of Sound,\\" as well as probably the next-best-known song on the album, \\"Fix You,\\" do not disappoint. On the aforementioned songs, as well as on some others, like \\"Little White Shadows\\" and the album opener, \\"Square One,\\" this works very well, and represents Coldplay on a par with its previous album, A Rush of Blood to the Head, which ranks in my top five favorite albums of all time. <br /> <br />However, despite these highlights, it cannot be said that this album is as good as Chris Martin and crew's prior efforts, for the simple reason that highlights do not a great album make. ARoBttH was a GREAT album. When I listen to it, I'm never satisfied unless I hear the whole thing, and never skip a single song. X&Y reaches the same highs (well, not quite \\"The Scientist\\" highs, but then, that's expecting a bit much), but tempers it with a few lows. I won't mention any specific songs, because I honestly forget which songs I've just been listening to after playing the less-enjoyable (in my opinion) second half of the album. But there are a few that I just don't feel are worth the effort to get through when I can just play the first half over and over again and enjoy it much more. <br /> <br />Fans who were expecting Coldplay to surpass their Everest of a musical peak will be disappointed, but those of us with more realistic hopes will be very satisfied with this effort. Considering the habit that musicians have of following up genius work with pure trash, Coldplay has done much to earn our confidence. X&Y may not be as fantastic as past Coldplay, but there are several more songs that must be added to any \\"Coldplay's Greatest Hits\\" playlist, and overall a very, very good, if not great, album is what Coldplay are happy to provide us with.

The plot is that Joel Backman, a former Washington wheeler-dealer, is pardoned from prison at the behest of the CIA so that he can be murdered by whichever assassins hate him most: Israelis, Chinese, or Saudis.  The CIA stashes Backman away in Bologna, Italy and waits for said assassins to find him, but Backman -- guess what? -- manages to escape and lead them all on a merry chase.  Whoopee!     The barest of plots is covered up by descriptions of fabulous Italian architecture, scintillating Italian coffee, sumptuous Italian food, elegant Italian fashions, intriguing Italian women, and endless lessons in how to speak Italian.  Methinks Grisham has a serious infatuation with Italy... and can hardly wait to show us his color slides and souvenirs.      Unless you're really desperate I wouldn't read this, but if you're really desperate you can skip over page after page without missing anything, including a climax that fizzles like overaged spumante. 6305535264|2.0|With hysterical dialogue like that, is it any wonder why this movie failed? Yet it has some redeeming values. <br /> <br />Those of you coming of age in the late 70's, early 80's like myself may remember this flick as one of many sci-fi thrillers emerging from the shadows of STAR WARS. I couldn't see SATURN 3 at the time because it was rated \\"R,\\" but I remained intrigued. <br /> <br /> <br />After finally watching it, I will agree SATURN 3 belongs in the \\"Cult Cheesy Sci-Fi\\" drawer. I could easily see this as late night viewing when nothing else is on the other 800 satellite channels. This is a movie that does not challenge the mind but instead puts it in suspended animation. With enough plot holes to fly fake spaceships through, it is best to sink into your favorite easy chair, pop open the Doritos and turn your brain off when watching SATURN 3. <br /> <br />The incredible aspect of SATURN 3 is not the \\"amazing\\" special effects (of which there are none), but the talented filmmakers and actors associated with its production, all of which could not save this movie from being as bad as it is.   <br /> <br />***MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS*** <br /> <br />No less than the venerable Stanley Donan (SINGIN' IN THE RAIN, CHARADE) is credited as director, and his direction here looks likes he's terribly out of his element. Elmer Bernstein's soundtrack is atrocious: cartoonish and more suited for a carnival funhouse. The screenplay by noted writer Martin Amis comes across like a college freshman thesis project. Why does Harvey Keitel want to go to Saturn 3 so badly, and what is his purpose in manufacturing this eight foot homicidal robot? Don't think too hard; these and many more questions will drive you mad if pondered. <br /> <br /> <br />Kirk Douglas is not bad as the aging scientist who gets to lay pipe with a nubile Farrah Fawcett (although I did not need to see his old flabby ass in one particular scene. Farrah's would have been much better). He spouts ridiculous dialogue created by the aforementioned Mr. Amis through clenched teeth, yet makes it all seem somewhat believeable. <br /> <br /> <br />Harvey Keitel at first seems wooden, robotic, in his delivery and acting, and it becomes clear that it is exactly how his character is: cold, efficient, bureaucratic. Although he speaks his lines in a steady monotone and an unblinking glare, this is a foreshadowing of him later literally becoming a machine. <br /> <br /> <br />Alas, Farrah Fawcett is by far one of the worst actors I've seen. She comes across as a life-size Betty Boop doll, clearly chosen as eye candy, her helium-filled delivery distracting and comical. Her much vaunted nude scenes are seconds long and unfulfilling, and as I've pointed out earlier, we see more of Kirk Douglas' craggy butt than hers. <br /> <br /> <br />The robot, Hector, is actually very interesting. I like how his body is composed of tubes of liquid, much like blood vessels. His body is monstrous and tank-like. His puny head atop this huge structure ruins the look and reminded me of the shrunken-headed guy in the Limbo waiting room from BEETLEJUICE.  <br /> <br /> <br />I remember reading an article about SATURN 3 in FANGORIA magazine when I was a kid, and I recall stills from this movie which depicted some gory scenes. In actuality, there is very little gore or blood, except for a guy at the beginning splattering like a watermelon, and Harvey Keitel having his very fake looking hand dismembered by Hector. Perhaps the gory scenes were edited out. Since the rest of the movie is so terribly edited, these scenes should have remained, and at least we would have had some good gross-outs to compensate for the rest of the dreadful film. <br /> <br /> <br />I did like the production design, which at least tried to make the sets look futuristic, despite the late 70's kitsch. The not-so-special effects are antiquated and cheesy by today's standards (and probably by late 70's standards), with lots of smoke and dry ice to simulate rocket propulsion and cardboard cut-out spaceships against a star-filled black screen. <br /> <br /> <br />One nifty feature (and since stolen by THE MATRIX) is the rear \\"port\\" in the back of Keitel's head from which he can \\"download\\" information and insert into Hector. Even the design of the \\"port\\" itself seems to have been lifted directly from this movie by the Wachowski Brothers. <br /> <br />Overall, an interesting but failed vintage sci-fi thriller that can be watched on a lazy Sunday afternoon or late at night when the brain waves are less active. Worth at least a rental. The DVD transfer is actually pretty decent, but it has no features other than a scene selection menu.

B00005JNJT|4.0|Or rather, the revitalizing of one. Batman has always been my favorite superhero, mostly for his lack of super-extraordinary powers and the darkness of his image. Unlike the all-American apple-pie wholesomeness of Peter Parker and Clark Kent and their respective counterparts, Bruce Wayne and his alter ego were always far more sinister. Menacing. Sombre. Unfortunately, the previous film renderings - even Tim Burton's much-beloved forays into the franchise - lacked this sense of dark inscrutability, ranging anywhere from the insanely Gothic to the unbearably campy, but always missing the true essence of the character. <br /> <br />Not any more. Christopher Nolan brings new life to the Caped Crusader, along with a more in-depth psychology and more believable methodology than anything seen previously. I cannot think of anyone I'd prefer as Batman than Christian Bale: he has a single-mindedness, a certain ferocity to him, that absolutely works for the driven character of Batman. He is in prime form here, demonstrating his usual dedication to the character and impressive talent, but he has got quite a supporting cast to back him up. <br /> <br />Not since the Lord of the Rings movies has such an extraordinary ensemble of performers been assembled in one film. These people are artists first, before movie stars, and it shows in their careful craft. The performers are not the only great aspect of the film, but they are essential to the mood: always realistic, they are nefarious or idealistic when appropriate. My particular favourites are Liam Neeson, elegant and paternal as always, but here driven by darker motivations than usual, and Michael Caine, who brings a humanity and emotional realism to Alfred that has not been seen before. He too is a father figure to Bruce, a nice touch that has been lacking from his usual function as a crusty facilitator. Also wonderful is Gary Oldman, who does a 180 from his usual slightly insane roles and embodies so much decent normalcy onscreen that it is slightly disconcerting in the midst of such madness. Indeed, the only weak spot in the casting is Katie Holmes as the dewy Rachel Dawes: she is amiable enough, but sorely outclassed in an otherwise exceptionally outstanding ensemble. <br /> <br />The production design is also outstanding. Gotham City is rotten to the core, to be sure, but there are observable vestiges of the grandeur that was, and also of the Wayne family ties to the city: Wayne Tower dominates the city centre, and the Wayne monorail - the pet project of Bruce's philanthropist father - is a now-dilapidated relic of better days. Its destruction near the end of the film is almost poetic. Batman's technology is not as advanced, but this I see as an improvement rather than not. The Batmobile, for instance, resembles an unlovely cross between a Lamborghini and a Hummer - far tougher and less sleek than the others, but practical for the demands of city-saving. I particularly like how it gets in and out of the Batcave. No fancy lifts or hydraulics here; it shoots - with a little help from its jet engine - through a waterfall into the Batcave, which is precisely that: a dark, dank, craggy mess home to some tens of thousands of bats. The Batsuit is something that looks like it might actually be an extant but neglected military prototype. And, perhaps most happily, it is presented sans the molded nipples and thong underwear, and even the \\"six-pack\\" is not ludicrous. The evolution of it, particularly the Cowl, is also entertaining to watch. All this combines to give this Batman a far more realistic tone, something the franchise has long needed. <br /> <br />But now let us return to Bruce Wayne for a moment. This is by far Christian Bale's most commercial film to date (ignoring 2002's largely forgettable \\"Reign of Fire\\"), but the actor gives no sign that he is a bona fide Hunky Movie Star in a bona fide Big-Budget Summer Blockbuster, giving another finely-tuned, pitch-perfect performance. His Bruce Wayne is subtle, nuanced, tormented not only by the demons of his childhood but those of his own dark soul. He is extensively trained but not entirely grounded; there are hints of madness in his dark eyes. Bale is debonair and suave, yes; he is completely believable and appropriately shallow in his playboy persona. <br /> <br />But more than this, he is scary. One would not want to meet him in a dark alleyway, nor would one want to get on his bad side. He inspires fear, not only as Batman, but as Bruce Wayne too; this is something the previous Batmans failed to do for me. Bale has always had an enormous talent for using his physicality to enhance his characters: in \\"Empire of the Sun\\" he went from a skipping, easy-going slip of a lad to a hard-bitten, almost feral survivor; in \\"American Psycho,\\" he was a ripped, six-pack-bearing, body-obssessed narcissist; in \\"The Machinist\\" he transformed into a walking skeleton, haunted nearly to his own extinction by his inner demons. Here, he is brawny, equipped again with a finely muscled physique that looks quite capable of beating the life out of someone. It is more than eye-candy here (although I'll gladly admit I'm happy to see him buff and beautiful again after his cadaverous turn in \\"The Machinist\\"): it makes the persona of the superhero believable when we know there is under the molded latex of the Batsuit a real, honed, physical weapon that could inflict definite and serious damage. <br /> <br />One is impressed, too, in this film that Bruce's alter-ego Batman is more than a way to shoot off steam after the playboy's partying. Unlike Peter Parker, who strives to live a normal life despite his superhero responsibilities as Spider-Man, Bruce Wayne needs Batman: the two are symbiotic halves of the same whole, neither equalling a whole person and neither capable of existing without the other. Bale captures Bruce's essential humanness without ever overplaying the role, bringing gravitas and dignity to the superhero genre.<br /> <br />This is definitely a Batman of the twenty-first century, informed by terrorism and 9/11. Rather than outlandish corporate villains and hedonistic monstrosities, the enemies here are idealists, warriors who fight for ideas rather than power. Ra's al Ghoul and his inscrutable League of Shadows operate covertly, infiltrating hierarchies, quietly sabotaging social structures, utilizing economic warfare. Here, they employ a biotoxin emptied into the water supply as a weapon; it is not to destroy the world, but to save it from itself. This allows for a far greater exploration of human motivation and psychology than has been attempted previously, and is far scarier than anything else I've seen in \\"hero\\" films. The film has received some criticism for not playing up to the younger, more comic-book atmosphere of the others, but this is precisely one of its biggest strengths. It is a very grown-up superhero flick, with adult concerns and adult methods on display. This Batman is part film noir and part action flick, but the two are married gracefully, bringing a long-overdue elegance to the franchise and offering the promise of several more fine outings to come.

006016848X|2.0|I read this when it first came out, mostly because the title was just too delicious to resist. I also liked the prospect of deepening understanding and \\"resentments melting away\\" that the book's cover promised. But when I read it, I found myself more and more resentful with each passing page. It took the laudable promise of bridging the gap and ended up strengthening what I thought were the worst stereotypes about the sexes.  Certainly men and women think and communicate differently, and that is something we absolutely need to remember when we deal with one another. But what those differences actually are do not follow simple little patterns that John Gray wants us to believe. He makes a few valid observations and extrapolates the rest, making stuff up to fill in the blanks.     Gray essentially recommends that you reduce human beings to oversimplified stereotypes and  use these as shortcuts to understanding them. He tells you to condescend to them as a group instead of recognizing them as individuals. What's worse, he tells you specifically not to recognize them as fellow creatures at all.       I do think that he does a decent job --AT TIMES-- of explaining some male behavior that baffles women (I have spoken to men who confirm that some of the explanations were accurate). But he really misses the boat when it comes to women. For example, according to him, it's NORMAL for women to get unbearably depressed on a regular basis and cry our eyes out for no reason and that men should just accept it! But I suppose it was well intentioned!

B0000C0FJB|5.0|A lot of people have complained about the mixing of this CD, and since Rush has always had high quality control standards, I can offer only this thought. <br /> <br />I've never - never - heard a crowd this energized for anyone.  I'm not sure they made this much noise for the Beatles at Shea in 1965.  Listening to this is almost like looking down on the band from the lawn seats, in terms of what I hear, and the crowd noise excites me as much as anything the band does here.  Maybe that influenced the band's decision not to emphasize their parts unnaturally in the mix, and anyway, I have had no problem making out the instrumentalists or what they're doing - particularly Lee, who gets the most clarity and warmth he's ever had on a live album without the benefit of a soundcheck.  Sometimes Geddy's voice and the crowd's tie for volume, but he's effortless and in pitch throughout. <br /> <br />Download Real if you don't have it, and listen to the samples here for a good idea of whether or not their mixing will bother you.  To me, several songs are given what sound like definitive renditions [\\"Big Money,\\" \\"Dreamline,\\" \\"Red Sector A\\"...and even if it's not the clearest recording ever, it's fun to hear Rio drown out Geddy on \\"Tom Sawyer\\"] and it would be a mistake to ignore the obvious exchange of energy and emotion between the band and the audience just because the audience hasn't been muted through the song and jacked artificially for the segues.  Casual fans of Rush might do without, but anyone who enjoys hearing Rush live will love this.
B000003TAW|5.0|Weezer began their career with a bang in 1994 with their self titled debut record. Their fun power pop style has made them a favorite to many people. They seem to get constant play every time they release a new single. So what made these nerdy guys so likable in the first place? It all started with this album. This was actually their biggest selling album to date and is considered a favorite among hardcore Weezer fans. I suppose the hit singles \\"Buddy Holly\\" and \\"Undone\\" didn't hurt either.     We kick off the record with the catchy, and imaginative \\"My Name Is Jonas\\",  which starts off with a nice acoustic riff into power chords and later in the song breaks off into some nice drumming and guitar work. It ends with the same acoustic riff it opened up with.  The next track \\"No One Else\\", singer Rivers Cuomo's lyrics sound demanding yet sung rather sarcastically. I like the short guitar parts that happen toward the middle of the songs. There are quite a few standout tracks on this album. \\"Buddy Holly\\" is defiantly one of note. The sheer catchiness of the song is undeniable. Next we come to \\"Undone\\" which is a dreary song with a catchy chorus. It's slow intro is outdone by the powerful chorus. The lyrics could mean a number of things. The sweater could be a dying relationship, loosing dignity, among other things.     The album is full of carefree moments such as \\"Holiday\\" and \\"Surf Wax America\\". Other tracks worth noting are \\"Say It Aint So\\" which Rivers confronts his feelings about how he dealt with his father's alcoholism.  \\"In The Garage\\" is one of my personal favorites about escaping to the place where you can do what you please without any problems. I can see this actually being written in a garage where the band practiced before actually making it big.  The album ends with the lonely \\"Only In Dreams\\" which is the longest song on the album. It dies down for a while before going into a long solo. It's pretty awesome. It provides a fitting end to a classic album. (41/2 Stars)

B000002TQV|4.0|Radiohead are one of the most versatile bands you will ever hear and extremely talented at that. From 1993's grungy \\"Pablo Honey\\" to later, more electronically driven albums like \\"Kid A\\" and \\"Amnesiac,\\" it cannot be doubted that Radiohead have some serious talent. But \\"The Bends\\" is certainly an album that has great musical validity and is the beginning of a journey of exploration for one of the most diverse bands ever to be formed...<br /><br />This album is almost purely an acoustic offering, but has touches of electric guitar and electronic samples that would later become the cornerstone of Radiohead's unique sound. In true Radiohead spirit, this album is beautifully sad, but also expertly executed. Thom's voice is wonderfully clear and really comes through on this album. The guitars are loud enough to be appreciated but do not overpower Thom's vocal performance. The drums are crisp and solid, with the electronics being more \\"carefully\\" blended in this album rather than more experimental work of later albums.<br /><br />\\"Fake Plastic Trees,\\" is a terribly sad song but really touches your soul, and is perfect for easy listening at the end of a long, hard day. \\"My Iron Lung,\\" deviates from the acoustic theme but purely adds to the flavour and experience of this wonderful collection. This song is also a forestaste of later, more liberal experimental work that Radiohead would carry out later on in their career. Perhaps \\"The Bends,\\" could be considered to be the perfect introduction to Radiohead as a whole since the album is not really \\"radical\\" as such, and really shows Radiohead beginning to move into different sectors in their music.<br /><br />To reveal more about this album would most likely ruin it for you. So I invite you to experience Radiohead first hand. Heck, borrow it, buy it, steal it, just give it a listen. If you like moderate rock that sticks, then Radiohead's \\"The Bends,\\" is the perfect album for you. If you don't enjoy experimental and acoustic work, then I suggest you look elsewhere; but personally I believe this album is pure, solid gold...work, then I suggest you look elsewhere; but personally I believe this album is pure, solid gold...

and teenagers who thing they are allready adults. according the the \\"bible\\" the vulcans have spent the 88 years from \\"first contact\\" to the building of the nx-01 impeadind whenever possible, the ability of humans to get beyond the sol system. <br />humans have been denied such things as warp technology, information on the verious political relationships beyond the sol system ( such as relations between vulcan & andor, the very fact that there is a klingon empire - let alone it's size and power, ect, ect, ect...)and even such simple things as a up to date star chart, as well as being limited to what other races humans do come into contact with. because of this commercially operated space freighters have more experience, and their pilots have more flying time than mid 22nd century starfleet. <br />     because of all of this the first 2 seasons of \\"enterprise\\" <br />bumbled, fumbled, and stumbled around the galaxy trying to explore without knowing the rules, while at the same time trying to avoid screwing up so badly as to warrent being called home and proving the vulcan high command correct. and having a first officer throught to have been placed on board to spy on the crew grew boring after a while. in additionthe temoral cold war sub plot was never understandable, because you never did learn who was fighting who and why.   <br />     by the time season two was coming down to its last few episodes, the show had crashed and burned, 75% of the viewership was gone (forever as it turned out) and the network, upn had switched the demographics, it wanted to go after ( let's face it, the type of viewer who would tune in week after week to find out at the end of the season which contestent will end up with the chance to be the next trya banks, most likely does not watch good drama on t.v., let alone good scifi, let alone star trek ) but after realizing their screw up, rick berman & co. decided the the \\"bible\\" was a failure and that if the show was going to be saved, some changed needed right away.  <br />    season three was that change, and by the end of the season the show was finally on track, but running out of time. the idea of a season 4, which forfilled all the  <br />hopes of the loyal viewers.  <br />     as for the future, i fear that the release of \\"enterprise\\" <br />will be the last new trek we will on either the 0156027321|4.0|Like C. McCallister (review on July 14, 2005), I find Life of Pi difficult to review. I agree that Martel writes exteremely well.  But contrary to McCallister I found the book easy to read after the first couple of chapters. Indeed, it was downright difficult to lay down when I was in its midst.  In fact, this to me is strictly the result of Martel's excellent writing skills: well-developed characters, easy-flowing prose, articulately described settings and character passions.    My problem with the book laid in its storytelling and content. I felt the whole point of the book was telegraphed by the telling. The unbelieveability of the behavior of the characters were at the core my issue. Hence, I found myself deciphering Martel's intentional puzzle from the get go. It was that simple. So for me there was no fear, no shock, and hence no underlying plot that threaded the story from start to finish. Nothing but Martel's excellent sentence-to-sentence and paragraph-to-paragraph writing carried me through from chapter to chapter.     Another measure of a book for me is how I am personally affected by it. In this case, I felt like I had done the reader's equivalent of eating a marshmallow. It was delectible in the reading, but what was the point?

1400032717|5.0|When I picked this up, I was in an airport looking for something that I hoped would entertain me during the two-hour filght. I am not a believer in reading best sellers; for me, they rarely make for good reads. But in a pinch, I pick them up on occasion and sometimes friends hand me dog-eared copies while extolling praises. In ths case, I grabbed a book that turned my head. Narrated by a 15-year old with autism, it was easily written. This makes the book's depth especially astounding. That is, the narrator's age and malady lend him an innocence that makes him apparently unaware of the various subplots that are obvious to the reader. This makes the book a masterpiece of sorts. That is, I cannot imagine that Haddon did not acheive all that he set to do in the context of this novel.  <br /> <br />I am not saying that this book deserves a Pullizer or that Mark Haddon should get a Nobel Prize. But there is something in The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time that everyone can enjoy. In fact, I believe that this book could become a Middle School and High School reading favorite. The upbeat tone and outlook of the book (yet narrated by an underpriviledged person) would make an excellent addition to the usual unfortunate conditions yielded in most of the significant reads extolled in schools today.  <br /> <br />The bottom line is that this book was a great treat. I hope other authors learn that you don't need to write in as lengthy and complex a style as John Steinbeck, Wallace Stegner, D. H. Lawrence, James Joyce, E. L. Doctorow, or Edward Jones in order to write a clever and enjoyable book. I cannot imagine, however, how Mark Haddon can top this one. Nonetheless, I will surely read his second novel.

B00005JKC3|3.0|this film was essentially unwatchable; however, it's worth fast-forwarding through just to see the most successful creation of a realistic, computer-generated human (or humanlike) character to date. the anatomical detail was remarkably well-defined, and although the movement was occasionally puppetlike, it was much less so than in other films such as spiderman. most impressive of all was the facial animation, which far surpassed the work in lord of the rings. the expressions were subtle and natural-looking; only a few contortions of rage seemed a bit artificial and unconvincing.  <br />I'm always mystified as to why these film versions change the most interesting elements of their cartoon sources. the hulk is perhaps most famous for his absurd, bewildered monologues, where he refers to himself in the third person a la tarzan. why make him mute? wouldn't it be irresistably fun just to mess around in a sound studio to come up with a voice for him? it makes me want to whack the director on the head with a rolled up comic book.

B000002HRE|4.0|I don't understand why some people dislike Load but quite like Reload. Having owned reload before I owned load, I think Load has some stronger songs on it overall, and less 'filler' than Reload. Note that the songs on Load/REload were all recorded at the same time for the most part. Metallica put what they thought were the 'best' songs on Load, you can be sure of that. Personally I agree with them; there's a lot of quality on reload but its not as good as Load. <br /> <br />I'm not going to bother to excuse Reload from the 80's Metallica stuff. Read my review of Load if you want to know WHY these albums can still be 'good', even in the face of Metallica's incredible 1980's work. Most people that don't like Load/Reload are people who ONLY like heavy music. THere's a lot of good songs on these cds if you only give it a try with an open mind. Be advised though, it did require a few listens for me to get used to this style of Metallica. Sure; classic cds shouldn't require several listens to 'like'. I agree; but this isn't a classic album. This is just an album that you may spend money on, and you may as well see if you can get into it and enjoy what you can about it. <br /> <br />Anyway, there are some outstanding songs on this album. THere's the opener fuel, a nice faster rocker with some good riffs. The Memory Remains is a weird song, with Marianne Faithful doing what my friends and I refer to as 'the grandma bit' at the end of the song. It's weird, but a fun song and not hard to like <br /> <br />Devil's Dance is a pretty good song; it has some interesting guitar effects. Unforgiven II is an excellent song; some may complain 'ehh, songs can't have sequels'. But why not? It isn't the same song remixed or anything, I don't see the problem. Its a good song in its own right. <br /> <br />Better than You is the first average song on this cd. It's not bad, but I find it a bit monotonous and it doesn't 'grab me'. Slither is much the same, I don't find the melody very attractive <br /> <br />Carpe Diem Baby, a weird title (yes I know what it means) but a pretty good song. Bad Seed has some cool riffs in it but I don't think much of the singing. <br /> <br />Where the Wild Things Are is a good track, very strange music but enjoyable nonetheless. Prince Charming is quite average and I can't find much to say about it <br /> <br />Low Man's Lyric is a wonderful song. BE warned, its quite an unusual MEtallica song; there's a 'hurdy gurdy', (i.e. a kind of keyboard/synth) and its a clean (i.e. not distorted guitar) song. But the subject matter is very touching and James sings is honestly. <br /> <br />Attitude is another average rocker <br /> <br />Fixxer IMHO is the best song on this CD. Its almost a companion to Outlaw Torn on Load; an 8 minute progressive song with some great guitar work, and lots of emotion. A great way to finish the album. <br /> <br />Overall, this is about a 4 star album. There's quite a few good to great songs on this CD, but some fairly average ones that drag the quality down as a whole. It isn't as well rounded as Load, but if you're open minded its a worthwhile investment. <br />

B000002HMH|5.0|I was VERY apprehensive about load to begin with. It was the last studio album that I bought, after having acquired all the earlier 80's MEtallica, and the Black album. THe reason? All the negative press from many of the people that loved 80s Metallica; mainly hardcore bogans.. The advice was usually 'don't buy it, its crap'. But when I inquired as to why it was crap, most people couldn't give me much of an answer. 'Its too mainstream' 'not heavy enough' 'sell out' was about as profound as the reasons came. Anyway I had faith in Metallica back then (before St Anger), so I bought Load because it couldn't possibly be 'that bad'. <br /> <br />My instincts proved me correct. There's no reason that I can see to justify viewing load as 'absolute crap' or anything close to that. On the contrary, it has lots of good songs on it. I don't want to be one of those fence sitters who says 'its just different' without accepting that something can be 'different and yet still bad'. Yet this is perhaps the best way to describe this album. Load isn't like older Metallica. It has a lot in common with the Black Album in style, with some more progressive elements and stylistic changes. (eg Mama Said - all acoustic 'country esque' tune) <br /> <br />THere's a lot to like on this CD for the open minded fan. Aint My Bitch, House that Jack Built, Until it Sleeps, Hero of the Day, Outlaw Torn, Thorn Within, to name a few. I'm not really that keen on 2x4 but hey its not bad. THere's nothing on this album that pains me to listen to it, unlike the HORRIBLE St Anger. My personal favourite is the beautiful 'Bleeding Me'. <br /> <br />So whats all the negative press about? I'm not going to justify my view by saying 'bands evolve - this is an evolution so its good.' Evolution can be a BAD thing if the music suffers. St Anger was an 'evolution' again (or more of a devolution) but it was absolute TOSH. Just because Metallica changed again didn't make the album not rubbish. WHats the difference then, between their change to that, and their change from the more complex, 80's style Metal into the style we hear on load? THe answer is simple - on Load, Metallica still demonstrate good songwriting <br /> <br />Ask yourself this - what do you want from Metallica? If you're only interested in really complex instrumentation, then load may not deliver for you. Go and buy music that caters for that; Steve Vai/Victor Wootton etc. Lars has downsized his drumkit and has dispensed with lots of pretty/extravagent tom fills in favour of keeping a tighter grip on things. But there's still a lot of creative drum work, its just more subtle. Listen to all the variations with the kick pedal/splash in Outlaw Torn and you'll see what I mean. <br /> <br />Load wasn't meant to emulate 80's Metallica, this much is clear. The band was evidently comfortable with what they'd done prior to load and wanted to keep themselves interested in music. They'd shown what they could do, technically speaking, they probably just wanted to write songs and try and stay relevant in the different climate of the mid 90's. <br /> <br />Load isn't Master of Puppets, and it never pretends to be. It doesn't try to be technically complex. That being said, Metallica really does deliver on this album as far as music is concerned. The boys still deliver some great songs that are easy to like. Again - this is why Load is good and St Anger isn't. Load was an evolution, but Metallica still produced good music and good songs. You'll still see some great songwriting on Load. St Anger was also an evolution, but Metallica decided to attempt to appease all the 'I dont like it if its not heavy' crowd, and so dispense with melody/rhythm and good songwriting in favour of white noise and tin can drumming.  <br /> <br />I know what I'd rather listen to.... <br /> <br />So overall, be open minded. Don't expect another Master of Puppets/And Justice for All. Expect an album full of great songs that you enjoy listening to. Don't expect heaviness for heaviness' sake (*Cough* St Anger) - expect to hear good music, and you may just find that you love this album.  <br /> <br />

0451199871|4.0|Agatha Christie (1890-1976) is the best known mystery novelist of the 20th Century--and with good reason, for when it came to plots, truly fiendish plots, she could easily out-construct all competitors.  She also had a knack for writing tongue-in-cheek, exhibiting a sly sense of humor for those sharp enough to catch it.  The 1942 THE BODY IN THE LIBRARY is an excellent example of both.<br /><br />The title is a classic cliche, immediately bringing to mind an old fashioned whodunit of the Mary Roberts Rinehart type, the sort of novel in which an improbable victim is discovered in an impossible setting.  But Christie twists the cliche, playing upon the idea in an darkly comic sort of way.  After all, what would you do if you awoke one morning to find a bleached blonde strangled to death and tossed on the library floor before the fireplace?<br /><br />As it happens--and most fortunately--Col. and Mrs. Bantry know an expert in all things homocidal: everyone's favorite spinster lady, Miss Marple.  When the victim is traced to a nearby resort, Mrs. Bantry wastes little time in booking rooms for both Miss Marple and herself and the hunt is on, complete with a series of unbreakable alibis, hidden motives, and a classic Christie plot twist at the end.<br /><br />THE BODY IN THE LIBRARY does not really compete with Christie's absolute best--but then few titles, regardless of author, do.  But it is among her most witty works, a fast-paced read that can be swallowed whole in a single sitting.  Recommended.<br /><br />GFT, Amazon Reviewer

I don't think anyone would argue with me on that.  In turn, he makes \\"Charlie and the Chocolate Factory\\" even creepier. One of Johhny Depp's best performances and a one of a kind horror movie. Definitely worth the price of admission and worth watching more than once.
B000084T18|1.0|vanilla ice can rap better than 50 cent somebody needs to get <br />a dollar buck and knock this RETARTED BITCH out
1592400876|5.0|OR - A WOMAN: WITHOUT HER, MAN IS NOTHING <br /> <br />How in the world does a simple book on punctuation get to be a best seller?  I think the catchy title helped attract attention - but the success of this book has to do with the outrageous, irreverent wit and personal charm of the author.  She writes about punctuation the way Erma Bombeck (bless her soul) used to write about being a housewife.  From page one, she points out how horrible life is for a stickler for punctuation, when most people \\"don't know their apostrophe from their elbow.\\"  You squirm with her as she gives unending examples of butchered grammar in public places.  As a teen, while other girls were \\"out getting abortions,\\" she resorted to midnight vigilante activities with white paint and magic marker on incorrect grocery store signs.  This author admits to mostly presenting an apology - a justification for existence - for punctuation.  Punctuation is traffic signs directing flow...If punctuation is the stitching of language; take the buttons off and the sentence falls apart...It's not the fault of the apostrophe that words need help identifying themselves...don't be the guy who believed there was no limit to the amount of clarification that could be accomplished if he just kept adding commas. <br /> <br />There have been great historical moments for punctuation:  The King James committee that allowed for Purgatory (pleasing the pope), or not (appeasing the protestants), by the placement of a comma (page 74, Luke 23: 43).  Apparently it was up for grabs because the Greeks didn't believe in punctuation.  A war was started by a confusing written message that could have been clarified by a comma.  \\"But heigh ho,\\" Truss says.   <br /> <br />Truss finally gets around to giving us some nuts and bolts:  The period is easy because it's so straightforward -  either it's there or it's not.  Apostrophes and commas have a few very definite rules, then a few irregular rules, then it becomes somewhat self-expressive and discretionary.  (I wonder, should I have used commas, semicolons or hyphens to punctuate the previous sentence! And should that exclamation point be a question mark)?  Should that question mark have gone inside the parenthesis?  There are fewer rules for explanation points, parentheses, dashes, elipses (which I like for lists of broken quotes but probably shouldn't use), semi-colons and colons.  In some cases it depends on whether you live East or West of the Atlantic ocean - and a huge faux pax on a seventh grade paper could be a clever syntactic move for Kurt Vonnegut.   <br /> <br />In this read, getting there is half the fun.  Imagine a book where suspense builds, as one wonders if he/she is ever going to get to the rules of punctuation.  For those who say, \\"What's the big deal - if I get my point across, that's all that counts!\\" - don't bother with this little book.  Instead, go wash your pick-up.  But if you're a little of a stickler yourself, you'll like it.
B00003CXCT|4.0|Yes, I'm another old-school fan of the original trilogy.  In fact, I have the original trilogy on laserdisc and transfered it to DVD for my own personal use, but the picture and sound quality is not up to par with modern DVDs.  It's better than VHS, but not quite good enough for the modern audiophile.    The sole reason I bought this set was to see and hear it on my home theater system.  I must say, the picture and sound quality is better than any Star Wars version I've ever seen.  My house literally shook when the Star Destroyers rolled across the screen.  Laser blasts seem to come at you from all directions as you become more and more immersed in the Star Wars universe.  In that aspect, it more than lived up to my expectations, hence the four-star rating. It does have a few audio inconsistencies which I expected since the movie is 28 years old, but it's nothing major. I had to take off one star out of spite, however.  Well-justified spite.    Visuals and acoustics aside, George Lucas killed the nostalgia of Star Wars when he made the special edition changes.  I see many kids writing reviews saying how much they love the changes, stop complaining, and so on and so forth, but many of them had never even *seen* the original trilogy before the prequels were released.  Obviously Episodes I, II, and III created a whole new generation of Star Wars fans.  Good for them; I hope their memories of the version they love will remain as fond as mine have for the version I love.    Therein lies the problem.  George has basically spit on my memories as well as those of other Star Wars purists who made him who he is today through our monetary support.  The ONLY special edition changes I can deal with are the explosions and improved quality of the picture and sound.  Everything else was either totally wrong to change or unnecessary to include.  I literally cringe when I see the special edition version of Jabba's palace in ROTJ.  Aweful.  And what's the deal with that scrawny, misshapen Jabba in A New Hope?  Did he really change that much in 5 years?  Why, oh WHY did he change the song in the Ewok village at the end of ROTJ?  That was the last thing I remembered about the original trilogy as a kid, and he destroyed it.  And I can't even bring myself to discuss how Lucas disrespected Sebastian Shaw (old Vader's ghost) by replacing him with Hayden Christensen during the final scene of the trilogy.  My god.    In conclusion, I'm glad that George finally released the trilogy on DVD, but I believe he should have more respect for his loyal, die-hard fans and release the original, unadulterated version on DVD as well.  If the purists didn't support him back in the day, there would BE no Episodes I, II, and III. There would BE no new generation of Star Wars fans.  Why he fails to realize this is beyond my comprehension.    I may bring out this set in case I'm entertaining a few youngsters or people who don't know much about the original trilogy, but I'll always prefer the 1995 laserdisc versions myself.
