B00005JNSK|4.0|Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, Tim Burton's make on the book by Roald Dahl and his remake of the 1971 classic: \\"Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory.\\"<br /><br />Johnny Depp plays Willy Wonka, a strange man who lives in a factory that makes lots of candy.  Some of it is strange candy at that (an everlasting Gobstopper and a piece of gum that holds breakfast, lunch and dinner).  Well, Wonka has decided to put Golden Tickets in his bars, five in total.  Five lucky children will be able to tour Wonka's factory.  Charlie, a poor boy who can't really afford any chocolate bars, stumbles onto the Golden Ticket after having a third bar.<br /><br />The other children who got these bars: A husky gentleman named Agustus Gloop, a rich snob named Veruca Salt, a champian named Violette and a boy who loves science named Mike Taevee.<br /><br />The movie isn't bad.  It's fairly good.  Johnny Depp makes a good Willy Wonka, but you can't replace Gene Wilder.  Johnny Depp is only good because he's good at playing strange characters, and Tim Burton often makes strange and dark films (films we love, no doubt).  Gene Wilder will always be Willy Wonka in my eyes.<br /><br />The look of the film is incredible!  Well, to put it simple, it's an update to the 1970's version.  Some parts look abosolutely stunning.  The special effects are top notch, and the Oompa Loompa's are pretty cool (considering only one person played all of 'em).  The songs the Oompa Loompa's sing are very good and very well choreographed.  They're NOT better than the songs in the original.  The original was more interactive and more riddle like.  This one is just here to be upbeat and \\"keep up with the times\\".<br /><br />However, the problem with this film is simple: It's virtually the same thing we saw in the 1970's version.  Some words of dialogue are almost exactly the same (Violet's monologue when she finds her golden ticket is word-for-word the same).  Everything that happens to the kids when they're \\"bad\\" is the same.  The only difference is that we get to see the kids afterwards, unlike the 1971 original.<br /><br />The changes in the story (which weren't a lot, but some were big) can sometimes be pleasant.  I didn't much care for Wonka's past, but they threw it in this film, and it made the ending a bit... stranger.  I was pleased that we saw what happened to the kids as well.  Wonka, is totally different than what he was in the original, and in the book.  Courtesy of Johnny Depp.  In the original he was a lonely guy but was testing to see if the kids would steal his greatest invention, the everlasting Gobstopper.  In this, there's no real test to see who should keep his factory.  It's all based on who the last kid left is (the one Wonka will say is the \\"Least rotten\\").<br /><br />It's a good film.  The look Tim Burton gives it is nothing short of brilliant.  The children who visit his factory are forgettable, except for maybe Charlie who manages to be BETTER than the original Charlie (although I was disappointed that the song \\"I got a golden ticket\\" didn't play when he got it).<br /><br />There are funny moments, some you'll die of laughter.  Johnny Depp delivers the character of Wonka very well, but as I stated before: Gene Wilder WAS Willy Wonka.  Filling Wilder's shoes is hard, and not even Johnny Depp (who after Pirates of the Caribbean seems to be the guy to get for your \\"strange\\" people) could surpass him.<br /><br />Before I close I will say one other thing.  The music is perhaps one of the best musical scores I've ever heard in a movie before.  Most Tim Burton films have excellent music, and this is no exception.  Each track goes along quite well with the situation.  The opening theme is the best one!<br /><br />Will fans of the original like it?  More than not.  Some will abosolutely hate it!  If you loved the original for it's characters and such: you probably won't like this one.  But if you enjoyed it for the story... it's nothing new, virtually it's theexact same as the original with an extended ending and update in it's look to make it more \\"modern\\".<br /><br />I'd say the original is better, but this one is just as good.  The characters (with the exception of Charlie) aren't really anything to write home about, but overall this is a good film.'s nothing new, virtually it's the exact same as the original with an extended ending and update in it's look to make it more \\"modern\\".   <br /> <br />I'd say the original is better, but this one is just as good.  The characters (with the exception of Charlie) aren't really anything to write home about, but overall this is a good film.

B00080ZG10|5.0|Nominated for 6 Golden Globes and 11 Academy Awards, including Best Picture, The Aviator wows audiences with its breadth of scenery and vivid realism. Director Martin Scorsese, known for a host of excellent films such as Raging Bull (1980), Goodfellas (1990), Casino (1995), and Gangs Of New York (2002) - not to mention the highly controversial The Last Temptation Of Christ (1988) - by no doubt turns out his best work since Tommy DeVito (Joe Pesci) sought to become a made man. The Aviator springs to life with nostalgic settings and a lavish tapestry of color and form, evoking all the enthusiasm indicative of Howard Hughes' unique lust for life. John Logan, known for such films as The Last Samurai (2003) and Gladiator (2000), presents a screenplay that provides some insight into the enigmatic Hughes and captures the mannerisms of those who shared that life with him. In short, the film is a masterpiece of visual imagery and first-rate cinematography few movie lovers can afford to miss... <br /> <br />The Aviator focuses on the early life (1930-1947) of America's most eccentric and bewildering billionaire playboy, Howard Hughes. Know for his seemingly erratic business dealings and fearless sense of adventure, Hughes (Leonardo DiCaprio) turned a small inherited fortune into an enormous corporate empire. And along the way, he captured the imagination of those around him with an attitude that embraced risk and life itself. Inheriting a majority interest in the Hughes Tool Company (founded by his father), Hughes embarks on a career in Hollywood where he produces a number of notable films including Hell's Angels, The Front Page, and Scarface. Hughes' obsessive dedication to perfection makes his stock rise in Hollywood and even helps launch the career of Jean Harlow... <br /> <br />But Howard Hughes is not just a one-trick pony, and his interest soon turns to the flourishing aviation industry where he becomes an integral part of TWA and pilots his own planes on a regular basis. His driving energy would lead Hughes to enter the defense industry, the electronics industry, Las Vegas casinos, and numerous other activities in the years ahead. But along the way, he deals with a cast of characters colorful in their own right. Romances with Ava Gardner (Kate Beckinsale) and Katherine Hepburn (Cate Blanchett) provide insight into Hughes' personal life, while Noah Dietrich (John C. Reilly), Hughes' assistant and right-hand man, sacrifices much in his own life to enable Hughes to live out his latest visions and inspirations. When Hughes makes the bold move of constructing the Spruce Goose - the largest airplane ever built (and able to land on water no less) - Senator Ralph Owen Brewster (Alan Alda) accuses the billionaire of war-profiteering. Hughes takes on the Senator full-force and with all the zest that marked his previous ventures. Vowing that the Spruce Goose will fly, in the face of highly publicized claims that it will not, Hughes proves his critics wrong, and the Spruce Goose rises to the occasion... <br /> <br />Despite its loss to Million Dollar Baby at the Oscars, The Aviator can take pride in being nominated as one of the best films of the year (along with Finding Neverland, Ray, and Sideways). And the film is certainly deserving of that high honor. Few films better illustrate the beauty of America, or more importantly, the mountains that can be moved when a single individual lives his life with ambition, drive, inspiration, and a naked enthusiasm for all that life has to offer. Overall, The Aviator is among the best films of the past several years, and movie aficionados would be well-advised to watch every last minute with same enthusiasm of a young Howard Hughes... <br /> <br />The DVD Report

B0007TKNL0|4.0|Nominated for 3 Academy Awards and 3 Golden Globes, including Best Motion Picture - Musical or Comedy, The Phantom Of The Opera is one of the most talked about movies of 2004. Taking the smash commercial success of Andrew Lloyd Webber's stage production to the big screen is no easy task, but long-time Hollywood director Joel Schumacher is more than able to get the job done. He takes an otherwise poorly written screenplay (minus the awe of a live performance no less) and manages to thrill the audience with the visual aspects of a film chiefly intended to rehash a successful stage musical. The costumes and set are simply magnificent, and Art Director John Fenner (Raiders Of The Lost Ark) helps Schumacher put together a fabulous production that's well worth a movie-goer's time... <br /> <br />The Phantom Of The Opera centers around a mysterious character who dwells underneath the Paris Opera House, imbibing himself on the music that emanates from above. Known as The Phantom (Gerard Butler), he wears a half-mask to cover the hideous facial scars that have plagued him since birth. A musical genius, the phantom is infatuated with the opera, and when he falls in love with the voice of a young chorus girl named Christine (Emmy Rossum - The Day After Tomorrow (2004), Mystic River (2003)), this love of the opera morphs into an outright obsession. The phantom provides Christine with one-on-one voice lessons, while during his spare time, he terrorizes the opera house in an effort to land his protg the opera's leading role. When Christine finally rises to that position, however, she is reunited with childhood friend Raul (Patrick Wilson), and the two begin a torrid love affair. Vengeful and jealous, the phantom kidnaps Christine and holds her prisoner in his underground lair, and Raul is the only one who can save her... <br /> <br />Onscreen, The Phantom Of The Opera is weak by the standards of a traditional film. The cast does its best to make the most of a screenplay peppered with rigid dialogue - a script designed to sell \\"the music of the night\\". The supposed magnetism between Christine and Raul is non-existent and not really believable. As such, the audience is forced into believing that the phantom (who, by contrast, is quite charismatic in this rendition) would end up playing second fiddle to a man who makes Al Gore seem animated. Overall, however, other aspects of the film make up for this flaw... <br /> <br />Based on Gaston Leroux's 1925 novel of the same name, The Phantom Of The Opera loses much of its original edge given the phantom's transformation from a frightening and mangled lunatic to a watered down half-scarred/half-babe-magnet figure complete with likeable characteristics. But inevitably, that's the mark of an enduring franchise - its malleability in the realm of numerous genres and the public's willingness to embrace such changes. But arguably, the small changes in the original novel's plot were necessary to achieve Lloyd Webber's goal of a melodramatic and stirring Broadway musical boasting mass commercial appeal. In a year in which the Oscar nominations were mostly dominated by lower-budget, surprise hit films (such as Sideways, Million Dollar Baby, and Finding Neverland), The Phantom Of The Opera holds its own in many aspects (given its pre-production designation as a commercial success). But those who have not seen the stage version are unlikely to be won over to the ranks of the franchise's numerous fanatics. My advice is to definitely see the film if you've ever seen the stage performance or listened regularly to the soundtrack - otherwise, you might be disappointed. After all, no matter how good The Phantom Of The Opera translates to the big screen, there's a reason musicals are not the dominate genre in Hollywood... <br /> <br />The DVD Report

Vic Mackey (Michael Chiklis, of The Commish) heads up an elite unit known as the Strike Team. An effective leader who bends the rules when they fit his aims, Mackey often butts heads with the by-the-book Aceveda who weighs his own political ambitions against the cost of bringing down Mackey and his associates. Veteran Det. Claudette Wyms (CCH Pounder, of ER) knows the ropes, admires Mackey, but also knows how to play sides of the game. B000000JO3|5.0|While some are quick to try to compare this album to Fugazi, there was no Fugazi when there was Minor Threat. Instead, this was the beginning of D.C. hardcore punk done at its best. That would seem like a stretch to some, but the tracks were not even meant to make a difference, yet did somehow anyway. If it were all about not having casual sex, drinking, smoking, or drug use, it wouldn't be the full mile of what makes it so great (although that's one factor that does). Minor Threat are capable of good songs, and you get 26 of them on this disc.    And only a handful of tracks are about what's mentioned above. What's misunderstood is that \\"Straight Edge\\" was not even a scene until people liked the message so much in the song. Only forty-five seconds, it was moving enough anyway. Many of the really short songs are also the easiest to get into. And then, if you live in D.C., you know how racially divided it is there, so it's nice to hear a track like \\"Guilty of Being White\\", which is an ode at being blamed for being racist (and causing slavery) for simply being white. And you get one that they even kid themselves on the band's antics, \\"Cashing In\\", something people have always wanted to accuse Ian's future band of doing. It also is a no-BS record, which makes me love it so much. You don't even have to be punk to like it, I know that I am not!    It is a compilation which was created so you could buy all of this for a low price as opposed to having to still cash out money for the two EPs (tracks 1-8; 11-15), Out of Step (15-23), and the \\"Salad Days\\" single (24-26). You get it all here, and the records are still sought after, since they've since become the punk thing... vinyl format. To me, that's what also makes it five stars is that Minor Threat have a lot of greatness in that it's just about enjoying the music. Not to mention both songs from the Flex Your Head compilation album appear here.

B000002NAK|3.0|First, I have to say that to those who say that this musical made them into Eva Pern fans... PLEASE go rewatch it, because you totally missed the point.    Anyway, I come from an interesting POV on this soundtrack: the \\"Evita\\" movie was one of my first exposures to musicals.  I think that a part of me loves it just because I grew up listening to it.  However, as I grew older and got more and more into musical theatre, \\"Evita\\" sort of faded into the background.  My friend has the OLC and he had me listen to it once; I found myself preferring the movie soundtrack.  This made me feel quite guilty.  I mean, what kind of a theatre fan did THAT make me?      But then when I saw the musical onstage, I realized how much the movie was missing.  I decided to check out the OBC, which is supposedly the best; though I was apprehensive because I am really not a Patti LuPone fan (I suppose that's musical blasphemy, but it's how I feel.  I saw her as Fosca in a filmed stage production of Sondheim's \\"Passion\\" and thought she was terrible)  So I now consider myself educated enough to make a solid judgment on this recording.    For starters, I love \\"Evita.\\"  It is one of four ALW shows that I actually like, and my favorite non-JCS show (I consider JCS in an entirely different league)  It's very unique to have a show include such intense politics, and also have a main character whom the audience is supposed to somehow like despite her being a total manipulative (...).    The instrumentals in the movie soundtrack are quite lush, probably because it's newer than the OLC and OBC.  I don't like some of the rearrangements, though.  But I do like how they actually give transitions in between the songs because the OBC tends to just jump into songs with absolutely no lead into them, which is a bit jarring.  Also, it annoys me how they cut out some of the coolest bits of the show.  Like the \\"Ride on my train, oh my people\\" line in the beginning that is so pretty in the OBC, it always takes meby surprise no matter how often I've heard it.    Madonna as Evita... I have never heard an Evita that I've loved.  Not even when a singer I normally love, like Marla Schaffel, does the role.  Everyone plays her as such a showy (...), singing very hard; it drives me crazy--I especially despise Julie Covington's portrayal.  Madonna doesn't, but she plays her too softly.  There must be a happy medium somewhere!  Vocally, she's okay.  Her breathy style gets on my nerves; she merely treads lightly when she should be pounding.  Because of this, she's unable to form an emotional connection.  She shapens up around when Eva gets sick... probably because her weak singing fits that of a sick person... but by then it's too late as there is no emotional connection.  I like \\"You Must Love Me\\" but the fact that it's there is sad.  It shouldn't have to be there.  Patti LuPone, probably my favorite Eva, actually had me almost crying without having to sing some simpering, out-of-character ballad.  Don't get me wrong, I like the song.  But not for Eva.    Some of Eva's good parts were removed too; a lot of her snippy lines were transferred to other characters, which took the edge off of her character.  Like many others, I was also upset by the decision to make Magaldi leave Eva instead of the other way around.      Antonio Banderas... I am going to come right out and say that I HATE how Che is always played by an old white guy onstage, like the type who plays Jean Valjean (I have yet to find more than one Che who HASN'T played Valjean at some point) when he's supposed to be this young, fiery Argentine.  Despite his lack of singing ability (though he is AMAZING in his original language of Spanish) and tendency to hiss out words instead of sing them, Antonio Banderas captures Che perfectly.  I didn't like Mandy Patinkin much (he sings like a 1930's salesman, he sounded bored throughout the OBC, and his Spanish pronounciation was TERRIBLE) and Colm Wilkinson, though I love him, just doesn't have the feel for Che.  I also like how the movie doesn't portray Che as Che Guevara; I think that ALW's making Che into the communist revolutionary was a ridiculously bad mistake; it ruins the character and isn't even historically accurate, as Che did not develop a political conscience until long after Eva's death.    What is unfortunate is how many of Che's great parts were removed.  Like the \\"What's new, Buenos Aires!?\\" part of \\"She is a Diamond\\" that I've always loved.    As for the minor roles... I've never much liked Jonathon Pryce; in this he is mediocre as always.  Of course, in the production I saw Pern was even less memorable; maybe it's because Eva totally upstages him.  And at least he doesn't have the horrendously fake Spanish accent the Pern in the OBC does.  As for Magaldi... he's not supposed to be amazing (\\"You'll never be remembered for your voice!\\") but he's supposed to be believable as a tango singer who makes all of the girls swoon.  This Magaldi did neither.    I agree that this version of \\"Evita\\" is a little too pro-Eva.  But, for a musical movie, it's actually pretty good.  ALW likes to sell out (coughPhantomcough) so we should be thankful that we got as good of a cast as we did. I think that overall though I prefer the OBC just because the movie soundtrack cut out so many of the good parts... and, of course, the singing is better.

B00000JAXT|5.0|In sharp contrast to the debut self-titled \\"Matching Mole\\", there's a great deal of evidence - to the ear alone - that each band member collaborated and contributed throughout the process from song-writing to final product.<br /><br />Robert Wyatt's presence, as always, obvious ... one very tall man regardless of his stature or, later, wheelchair.<br /><br />Bill McCormick: a soloist, a tunesmith, and a solid reliable Canterbury sound.  And that's precisely what a bass player should be in this context.<br /><br />Phil Miller always seemed to have to suffer pain to play.  He puts an incredible amount of effort into doing what he does, and it showed when I saw him live.  I was happy to hear him more to the fore, both playing and writing.<br /><br />Dave McCrae. He's no Joe Zawinul, he's Dave McCrae.  This album made his mark for me.  He pushed the early 70's gear further than it was designed to go, and without him this album would not be so remarkable. As good as Dave Sinclair was, I don't think he could have managed the same effect.<br /><br />Miller and McCrae give the whole direction of the album more of a fusion sound than the first album had, and although some feel it doesn't work too well, I disagree strongly.<br /><br />The most notable difference, however, is the atmospheric contribution of Brian Eno on VCS3.  Don't expect to hear something of what might now be called the \\"Eno sound\\", though. This was before digital, where synth players had to know about the construction of sound as well as the construction of music.  Eno gives an air of Morton Subotnick, The Twilight Zone, and inhaled surrealism to this album.  Not Roxy Music, not Music For Airports.<br /><br />The same goes for Bob Fripp's production ... this isn't Swastika Girls, not Septober Energy (although it comes close). There's an occasional production glitch - most notably with keyboards being a little too hot (to my ears, perhaps not yours), but without detracting from the music.  I'm glad that's all he did; his guitar is not what I'd want to hear on this album<br /><br />All together, the tracks form a whole experience.  Of course the original was on vinyl, two sides with the natural break between each.  But played on CD, straight through from beginning to end, it's more of a journey.<br /><br />I've read that one reviewer discarded this album after one listening.  Only one!!!  So much music has been rejected without effort!<br /><br />It's not only the reviewer's loss, but also a loss for you if you follow his advice and not bother with this album.  Sometimes good music takes more than one handful of hearings to make itself clear.  And that's true for most of Robert Wyatt's work until you accept him as he is.<br /><br />Wyatt has the rare ability to create poignantly serious lyrics and music that are filled with humor and romance with a tinge of surreal strangeness.  In that, he's a poet and an artist.  But in all the covers of his songs that I've heard, the elements only come together when they are sung in his unique voice.  That was true for the debut album, and it's no less true for the second and last release during the band's lifetime.<br /><br />Put that together with the obvious skills of the other musicians, and what have you got.  It's probably \\"Music for musicians\\" more than it is \\"Music for the masses\\", which seems a little out of place given the album title, and Wyatt's burgeoning political voice.<br /><br />Take the time, make the effort, and you will be rewarded.  Sure, it's a typical example of 1970's progrock in some ways.  I bought the album when it was originally released in the UK, and it does begin to sound a little dated.  But there is still an overwhelming uniqueness to the whole thing.  There wasn't anything exactly like this before, and there hasn't been anything exactly like this since.  For me, it will always be a landmark in my musical journey. Listen to it, and find out where it takes you.  Explore.<br /><br />Choice picks: GloriaGloom, God Song, Righteous Rhumba, Nan True's thingy (virgin sex!!), and of course SITMOTDWCDOPA.  Hahahaha!  Darn it, the whole album. Sex, laughs, music, drinking, politics... what else is there?  Religion.ong, Righteous Rhumba, Nan True's thingy (virgin sex!!), and of course SITMOTDWCDOPA.  Hahahaha!  Darn it, the whole album. Sex, laughs, music, drinking, politics... what else is there?  Religion.
B0006L16N8|2.0|Coldplay's dangerously close to being a victim of its own success, and X&Y embodies this tragic development in their overreliance on formula, demographic hippieness and industry presssure to be BIG, big, big--the next U2!!--most of all.  The brilliance of Coldyplay's earlier albums lay in a quirky sensitvity; with X&Y, every single track is overengineered, overly measured, and too self conscious of its popularity to make the listeneer want to actually listen.  martin seems to rotate between a prozac-improved Bob Dylan and nicer but just as egotistical version of Clapton in his lyrics and singing style, and the songs, many of which have potential to be great, get lost in the band's tendency towards anthemic display of synthesizer grandiosity.  \\"Fix You\\" for example, could be a beautiful little song if they had some creativity with the actual music--Speed of Sound, which so many people rave about, was entirely disappointing--a monochrome of obnoxiousness--as though the listeners are so stupid as to not need a little variation in the music.   They seem to be unsure of whether to become a band known for performance, or for artistry.  As a result, they deliver very little, and I was left feeling as though each song came close to something interesting, and then lost it in its own anxiety of itself.  Perhaps if they hadn''t become so popular, they might have traveled down different paths creatively.  As it is, it's become a band that seeks a cult following--which is to say, a following that blindly follows.

B00004W52U|5.0|While relatively well-known within the confines of the punk genre, Operation Ivy never really got the same kind of publicity Rancid would achieve later on during the 1990's. I think it would be a bold statement saying this, but Operation Ivy completely surpassed anything Rancid has ever accomplished in their career... and they did it with this very album.<br /><br />It's not hard to point out why this album is such a hit among fans of third-wave ska and punk rock: the energy that flows from vocalist Tim Armstrong's voice is unparalleled. The whole band is on fire for the entire span of the album, and each song has a unique feel to it. Operation Ivy were known for their two-minute numbers dealing with numerous kinds of topics: from anti-war (\\"Unity\\") to discipline (\\"Gonna Find You\\"), Operation Ivy covered it all and went to show that even \\"punks\\" had brains of their own. In many ways, this self-titled album is proof that even punk rock can be smart. While not nearly as political as predecessors The Clash (another important punk band), the genius lyrics of Operation Ivy are one of these reasons I enjoy them so much.<br /><br />Another thing I'd like to point out: it's very evident that Operation Ivy had many different inspirations while recording this album -- and no, I'm not referring to drugs. The bluesy nature of both guitar and bass lead me to think that the guys all grew up listening to blues. The punk and ska roots are also very evident, more so in select songs than other. These three genres combined form one very likeable song, and the (although brief) solo's on this album is where the boys shine the most. Whether it's the bass is pumping out or there's a guitar riff screeching its way into the mix, it goes to show that the guys were comfortable with their respective instruments. Armstrong's voice isn't the high point of Operation Ivy, but I find that it fits quite well with the punking feel Operation has going on.<br /><br />Overall, this truly is one of the greatest punk rock albums ever. You either hate them or love them, but after hearing this, I'm inclined to think that you'll be spending a lot more time listening to Operation Ivy.the greatest punk rock albums ever. You either hate them or love them, but after hearing this, I'm inclined to think that you'll be spending a lot more time listening to Operation Ivy.

B00004BZ0N|5.0|To this day, The Clash have remained one of my favorite punks bands to listen to. However, don't be so fast to label them \\"punk\\" in the same sense as other legendary bands like the Sex Pistols and The Ramones. The Clash, aptly known as \\"The Only Band That Matters\\" courtesy of Rolling Stones magazine, are anything but your stereotypical punk rock group. They bring to the table almost every genre of music possibly imaginable, and they do so superbly and better than anyone else. Whether it's jazz, ska, good old-fashioned rock n' roll, reggae, punk, hip hop, blues, etc., The Clash put it on display in London Calling.<br /><br />London Calling first came out sometime during the month of December in 1979. This was one of the years when punk rocks flame was clearly beginning to burn out. With this release, the light definitely flickered at least once or twice. This was The Clash's third record, and has been considered by many to be their greatest achievment. In fact, London Calling was given the honorable award of \\"Best Album of the 70's\\" by Rolling Stone! With all of this in mind, I think you should already be sold on the idea that maybe this double-disc album really is something special.<br /><br />For those of you that are not yet sold, however, I'll go song-by-song and give you an idea on why I highly recommend London Calling. It all starts with ringing guitar strums, followed by a deep bass line. These chords of course being the introduction to not just the CD, but the CD's title song, London Calling. Twenty-five years later, this track is still being called one of the greatest songs ever performed. The legend that is Joe Strummer makes his presence felt by churning out some awesomely political lyrics, aiming right at The Clash's hometown of London, England.<br /><br />London calling to the faraway towns<br /><br />Now that war is declared-and battle come down<br /><br />London calling to the underworld<br /><br />Come out of the cupboard, all you boys and girls<br /><br />London calling, now don't look at us<br /><br />All that phoney Beatlemania has bitten the dust<br /><br />London calling, see we ain't got no swing<br /><br />'Cept for the ring of that truncheon thing<br /><br />The ice age is coming, the sun is zooming in<br /><br />Engines stop running and the wheat is growing thin<br /><br />A nuclear error, but I have no fear<br /><br />London is drowning-and I live by the river...<br /><br />Following up is two of the more bluesy, rock-a-billy songs, Brand New Cadillac and Jimmy Jazz. Both have a very retro 1950's style, especially taking into consideration the way the bass is incorporated into the songs. Brand New Cadillac is particularly simple, which makes it so much more fun to listen too. Sometimes the simplicity of certain Clash songs overshadows the more complex ones. This definitely holds true in the second and third affairs.<br /><br />From the 1950's to a less distant sound, the 70's own ska and reggae, The Clash pull out two more familiar sounding numbers, Hateful and Rudie Can't Fail. Hateful is one of the faster songs on London Calling, and I can't help but say that I really enjoy the chorus in it. Call it what you wish, I say it's catcy as all hell.<br /><br />Oh, anything I want he gives it to me<br /><br />Anything I want he gives it, but not for free<br /><br />It's hateful<br /><br />And it's paid for and I'm so grateful to be nowhere<br /><br />Rudie Can't Fail gives me a very Jimmy Buffet-like impression, and it's quite obvious that The Clash were heavily influenced by reggae artists when they were either much younger or while they were writing songs for London Calling. Rudie Can't Fail is also very positive sounding, and the chant of \\"Ruuudie can't fail!\\" is loads of fun.<br /><br />Spanish Bombs returns to the more punkish side of the boys, and politics are again throw into the mix. It also includes the chorus being sung in Spanish, which is really cool. This is a very monumental track, and it hasa unique punk sound while again still maintaining a positive sound. If there's anything that The Clash don't do, it's write extremely depressing songs. Spanish Bombs is one of the better songs on London Calling.<br /><br />Spanish weeks in my disco casino<br /><br />The freedom fighters died upon the hill<br /><br />They sang the red flag<br /><br />They wore the black one<br /><br />But after they died it was Mockingbird Hill<br /><br />Back home the buses went up in flashes<br /><br />The Irish tomb was drenched in blood<br /><br />Spanish bombs shatter the hotels<br /><br />My senorita's rose was nipped in the bud<br /><br />The only song I don't really connect with is The Right Profile. It goes more along the lines of sounding like earlier song, Brand New Cadillac, than anything. But opposed to its predecessor, the song is just no fun. The only good thing I can think of it showcasing is the ska-based instruments in the background, which don't really do much for the song in the longrun.<br /><br />Song number eight is another classic, Lost In The Supermarket. As the quietest song on London Calling, it puts to use some unforgettable lyrics and musicianship. The chemistry between the band shines in this one, and Strummer's voice only adds to it all. Definitely in contention with Spanish Bombs and London Calling...<br /><br />The rest of London Calling more or less follows the ways of the tracks I just talked about. More than anything, I loved Death Or Glory, Lover's Rock, and Stand By Me. Death Or Glory was the very first song I connected with from The Clash, and upon listening I'm sure you'll see why. Another song, suitably titled Koka Kola is about - you guessed it - drugs, and it's very fast demeanor is sure to leave you dizzy and trying to keep up.<br /><br />In the end, The Clash's London Calling is perhaps the greatest album I've ever had the privilege of hearing. With comparison to a lot of other punk bands, The Clash really was the only band that mattered. After you hear what's in store for you on London Calling, I'm sure you'll be inclined to believe the same.ing a positive sound. If there's anything that The Clash don't do, it's write extremely depressing songs. Spanish Bombs is one of the better songs on London Calling. <br /> <br />Spanish weeks in my disco casino <br />The freedom fighters died upon the hill <br />They sang the red flag <br />They wore the black one <br />But after they died it was Mockingbird Hill <br />Back home the buses went up in flashes <br />The Irish tomb was drenched in blood <br />Spanish bombs shatter the hotels <br />My senorita's rose was nipped in the bud <br /> <br />The only song I don't really connect with is The Right Profile. It goes more along the lines of sounding like earlier song, Brand New Cadillac, than anything. But opposed to its predecessor, the song is just no fun. The only good thing I can think of it showcasing is the ska-based instruments in the background, which don't really do much for the song in the longrun. <br /> <br />Song number eight is another classic, Lost In The Supermarket. B000002LJW|3.0|There's no denying that all of Clapton's best albums come from the 60s and 70s (his work with Cream, Derek and the Dominoes, Blind Faith, and his early solo albums). That being said, there were times after that when he didn't totally give in to tendencies to pap and this is one of them. Producer Russ Titelman updated his sound for the 80s with keyboards and drum machine but did it tastefully so that the album doesn't really sound \\"dated\\".<br /><br />HIGHLIGHTS:<br />The song's writer Jerry Williams joins Clapton for a harmony vocal and additional guitar on \\"Pretending\\". EC lets go some nicely restrained guitar and the chorus is buoyed up by peppy synth horn along with Chaka Khan's guest vocals. Extremely 80s keyboard pads start \\"Bad Love\\", briefly leaving you to fear you're in for a power ballad..that is until Clapton unleashes the most potent riff on the disc. Phil Collins guests on skins and harmony vocal as Clapton howls \\"Had enough bad love/I need something I can be proud of\\". It's punctuated by a stinging solo at about 3:25 in and it's one of the better ones written by EC here (with help from Mick Jones of the Clash).  Robert Cray joins Clapton for a bluesy shuffle on classic \\"Before You Accuse Me\\". It's one of the more \\"organic\\" numbers here with only a trace of synth. \\"No Alibis\\" gets help from Daryl Hall and Chaka Khan on vocals.<br /><br />LOWS:<br />\\"Hound Dog\\" is nondescript: it could really be anyone playing it. To his credit, EC takes his inspiration from the Big Mama Thornton version rather than Elvis' cover. \\"Running on Faith\\" is an overstuffed faux gospel number. The lyric for \\"Lead me On\\" is pallid. (\\"Lead me on,lead me on/Lead me on,lead me on/I'll play along and along and along/Baby lead me on\\").<br /><br />BOTTOM LINE:<br />It's not a \\"must have\\" Clapton album, but any Clapton fan will probably enjoy more of it than not. It's aimed at the charts but not the sappy adult contemporary fare he'd head toward later. If you're just dipping your toes in, though, and want to find out what Clapton's all about, pick up THE CREAM OF CLAPTON (ASIN B000001EEA) as your primer.<br /><br />3 1/2 starsClapton's all about, pick up THE CREAM OF CLAPTON (ASIN B000001EEA) as your primer.    3 1/2 stars

0393312836|5.0|To the reader who declared, \\"The theme I'm told is, 'is it better to choose evil than to be forced to do good,'\\" I have to point out that this is a misreading of Burgess' intent. The problem, or question, posed by this \\"nasty little shocker,\\" (as the book was called by Burgess himself, if I'm not mistaken), comes down to \\"what does it mean to be human, to be a moral creature?\\" In other words, why did God create humankind with free will? Why would He allow His creatures to commit evil? Wouldn't He have preferred His creatures to act peacefully and benevolently, such that he would have made them incapable of choosing malevolence and violence?    The title itself, \\"A Clockwork Orange,\\" refers, according to Burgess, to something which has the appearance of life, but which is mechanistic, its actions predetermined. An orange is an organic object, which grows naturally, while a \\"clockwork orange\\" merely apes the appearance of an organic, growing object: it is a construct, a machine which cannot change and which cannot act other than how it has been designed to act.    As a catholic, Burgess wanted to demonstrate that God gave his creatures free will--choice--in order that they come to moral behavior out of their own reasoning and spiritual/moral maturation. In other words, had God's creatures lacked the capacity to behave brutally and with evil intent, they could never become moral creatures, as they would only have been machines, capable only of acting as they had been designed. Such creatures are not alive in a spiritual sense, but are windup toys which simulate the activity of life but which are dead. Machines have no morality, and neither do creatures who cannot choose their actions. Each major section of the novel begins with the question, \\"What's it going to be then, eh?\\" A machine cannot ask or answer that question, but can only hum along performing its limited, thoughtless reflex actions. Animals, similarly, despite being organic creatures, behave largely mechanistically, in that they do not have a morality, but behave according only to instinct and inborn impulses which allow them to survive in an unforgiving but morally blank environment.     It is our capacity for free choice, even when we choose to behave evilly, which allows us to develop a morality, and this distinguishes us from animals and machines, and it is what makes us God's creatures. That Alex appreciates music and adores Beethoven indicates he has an aesthetic, a capacity to enjoy that which is not merely related to the brutal imperatives of survival, and it is this which signifies his potential for deeper human growth.    (I must point out I am an atheist, but I am speaking via the terms of Burgess' own thinking.)    The final chapter of the book, which was truncated from the original American edition of the book, and likewise from Kubrick's film, illustrates Burgess' point: in it, Alex has grown a bit older, he's perhaps in his early 20s. He's married, has children, and looks back on his career of teen hooliganism with a nostalgic enjoyment, but he's also grown out of it, and he realizes that one cannot always live such a life. He has grown in years, in experience, and he has developed a morality. Had he not been \\"cured\\" of the government's behavior modification treatment, he might never again have behaved violently, but it would not be because he had grown out of it, had CHOSEN to leave it behind. It would have been only because he could NOT have acted in any other way. He might have always harbored violent desires, or he might have had NO desires, but he would not have been a creature of God, a moral creature, because the chance to grow into that state would have been denied him. He would have been a \\"clockwork orange,\\" and not a human being.

B000935UGM|4.0|Ryan Adams is an overblown egomaniac. Ryan Adams is an underrated musical genius. Most listeners of his music fall into those camps, and the debate lives on. But one thing cannot be denied: Adams is a very good musician, and his brand of whiskey-soaked alt-country is in good form in \\"Cold Roses.\\"<br /><br />The two-disc album not terribly new territory, with echoes of \\"Heartbreaker,\\" albeit more subdued. And as the first of three scheduled albums this year, with his new band the Cardinals, hopefully \\"Cold Roses\\" representative of what Adams is going to stick to in future. It's certainly what he's good at.<br /><br />The songs here tend towards bluesy, midtempo rock, with countryish guitars and solid drums. The Cardinals are definitely a band that suit Adams' style, and they have a comfortable feel, as if they have been playing with him a long time. Songs like the gritty country song \\"Cherry Lane\\" are among the highlights of the album. There are also some slower, softer numbers like the poignant \\"How Do You Keep Love Alive,\\" which balance out the more robust songs, and show the softer side of Adams' music.<br /><br />Like many other two-disc albums, \\"Cold Roses\\" does suffer a little from double-disc syndrome, wherein some of the songs feel like they were put in to flesh out the tracklist. Fortunately, this is restricted to only a couple of songs. The majority of songs are strong and solidly written, with a well-worn sound like that of a comfortable slipper.<br /><br />After a few years of experimentation -- through the deeply forgettable \\"Rock'N'Roll\\" and the lovely acoustic \\"Love is Hell\\" -- now Adams is back at his roots. The Cardinals are guitarists J.P. Bowersock, Cindy Cashdollar, bassist Catherine Popper, and drummer Brad Pemberton. They all do marvelously, especially since they are an experienced band, with prior work with people like Heather Nova, Hem, and past work with Adams himself.<br /><br />Adams's voice is scratchier than in his past albums, but except for a few strained vocal moments, he sounds a bit world-weary but pleasant. He also gets joined by singer-songwriter/pianist Rachael Yamagata on three songs on the second disc, playing her instrument and lending her pretty voice to Adams' older, rougher one.<br /><br />Bluesy country-rock is where Ryan Adams belongs, and he does well with his new band the Cardinals. Here's looking forward to Numbers 2 and 3 this summer and fall.st albums, but except for a few strained vocal moments, he sounds a bit world-weary but pleasant. He also gets joined by singer-songwriter/pianist Rachael Yamagata on three songs on the second disc, playing her instrument and lending her pretty voice to Adams' older, rougher one.  <br />  <br />Bluesy country-rock is where Ryan Adams belongs, and he does well with his new band the Cardinals. Here's looking forward to Numbers 2 and 3 this summer and fall.

0743435729|4.0|In my opinion, this second book is better than On Basilisk Station. Weber seems to be more confident in his characters and his writing style. The dialogue and the story unfold at a much more natural pace and there is hardly any techno-babble (which was the biggest sore spot for me in the first book). <br />  <br />I don't read book summaries anymore (they give as much away as theatrical previews, if not more), so I had no idea what the plot was about. When it became obvious that Honor would be dealing with a backwater planet full of sexist religious fanatics, I groaned. It's become pretty standard fare for SF/Fantasy to take real world examples of religious fools and use a broad brush to paint all religious people as such. Fortunately, Weber proves to be more subtle than that and goes to great lengths to demonstrate how having misguided notions (fostered through many generations in isolation) doesn't necessarily make one a completely worthless individual. There are good men on this backwater planet who are trying to do their best according to the ways they've been taught. In fact, he even turns the tables just a tad and shows how arrogant and self-righteous those who are \\"enlightened\\" can be. He's not afraid to let his hero, Honor, make stupid decisions based on her own pride and preconceived notions. <br /> <br />Of course, this does not even touch on the overall plot, which I won't bother to summarize, but I liked it. The continuity with the first book is there but not off-putting and the characters actually appear to be changing in realistic ways. Still wouldn't rank him up with Bujold (while Weber's plotting and characterization are fine and he builds realistic characters, his use of language simply doesn't compare), but there's nothing wrong with that. He writes a good story and, ultimately, that's what counts.
B0000DD7LC|2.0|IM SO SORRY BUT IF I PLAYED THE PIANO AND SING ABOUT A MAN I NEED WOULD I GET A GRAMMY 2 LMAO. SHE IS ALRIGHT SHE IS OVERATTED AS WELL AS MARIAH CAREY'S LATEST ALBUM THEY BOTH ARE SOILD ALBUMS
0823016714|3.0|Every artist should have a facial expression book on the shelf--but maybe not this one. The most baffling deficiency of this book--and it's a biggie--is that the faces are organized by age, not emotion!! Maybe someone can convince me that a 33-year-old face differs from a 34-year-old face in displaying emotion and that should be the basis of organization in this kind of reference book. So each age-identified model gets a gallery of random mug shots which are unlabeled to emotion. Apparently the author \\"inspired\\" each model with a laundry list of emotions and they twisted their faces this-way-and-that before the camera and you can make of the results what you will. So if you need a quick facial reference for \\"thinking\\" or \\"rage,\\" for example, you have to thumb through countless pages until YOU believe you've spotted the correct visage. The author then throws in a \\"kissing gallery\\" out of the blue as the only pages on two-person interaction. (Why not a \\"fist-fight gallery\\" instead?) What maybe salvages this haphazard work is the phonemes gallery of mouth shapes from speech sounds if you're into animation. For better books on this subject, I recommended, first off, the great Stephen Roger Peck's Atlas Of Facial Expressions. Peck not only organizes his book by emotion, he elaborates on the elements that go into each facial expression. Also worthwhile is Illustrator's Reference Manual Hands & Faces which presents the material in color and from different perspectives. And you can never go wrong with Jack Hamm who covers the subject in his typically succint and understandable way in Cartooning The Head And Figure.

B00007BK2N|4.0|SOMEWHAT OF A SPOILER NEAR END - The item may be common knowledge to fans of this music scene (or may not).  It is also presented pretty early in the movie but it the weight of it is not actualized until the end of the movie.  So it probably isn't really considered a spoiler, but I am giving the warning just in case.    ********    The time period was the greatest time period in underground music.  Hardcore punk and extreme metal underground was at it's strongest before degenerating into a sub-genre of pop music as it now stands.    As always happens, bridges are always being built joining popular culture and independent cultures.   The extreme music scene of the 80s unfortunately had spawned more than it's share of these musical bridge culture experiences.    Nu Wave - bridging punk and pop  Grunge - bridging punk, extreme metal and pop.  Alternative - bridging punk and pop.  The Sub-pop bands - a particularly annoying subsection of alternative.  Industrial - bridging extreme metal and pop.  Nu Metal - bridging death metal and pop.  and a whole slew of \\"edgy\\" mainstreamers such as NIN, Marilyn Manson, White Zombie.    All this watering down of genres does is to dilute it to the point that it no longer effectively exists, minimally affects pop culture, and can no longer regain its purity due to the ever dilluding association.    This movie describes itself at looking at the Manchester \\"punk\\" scene which shows how the word punk has lost every aspect of it's definition in use today.   This is alternative pop clear and simple.    This is a scene I totally despised back in the day and still hate now.  But I was surprised at how much I liked this movie.    This movie has a lot of bad reviews and I see a lot of bizaare criticisms of it.    One said it was a \\"mockumentary worse than Best in Show\\".  This is not a mockumentary.  It is a true story and quite an interesting one.    Others complained that Tony Wilson was a despicable character.  This is utter nonsense and showsthe vicious twisted values of pop culture.  Quite the opposite, this movie presents Tony Wilson as an angel of person giving entirely of himself for the sake of the music and the artists.  If this movie is an accurate portrayal of him, Tony Wilson self-destructed by his own extreme generosity and authentic love for the genre.  I still view it wasted being in the service of garbage music but this movie shows Tony Wilson of holding extreme virtue.  The total opposite of a despicable character.    This movie shows Tony Wilson falling in love with the sprouting alternative scene in Manchester and investing himself totally into it and its promotion.  It shows his creation of the Hacienda Night Club and Factory Records.      It presents this in a unique stylish manner (which probably appears similar to the Spinal Tap style confusing the other reviewer that this was a mockumentary) that actually works for the movie.  It is also one of the few movies that properly utilizes self-reference by introducing information while reminding us that it's main purpose is to tell a real story.    I didn't know the story of these events before but I assume the main points are correct.    You will see the sincerity of Tony Wilson as he gets run over by the very bands he is promoting, his many struggles, and the many unique situations in the music business.  The music exploded but Tony's mismanagement in business structure caused Factory to struggle along financial always near collapse.  For Tony it was all about the music.  He had great skill in promoting the scene but almost no skill in taking the money out of it for himself.    Finally, Factory failed and Tony would have then been able to cash in for big money by selling the entire business to other more business focused parties.  THE MILD SPOILER>  However, if the movie is correct, the only contracts Factory had with their bands was that each party had \\"the freedom to f**k off\\".  They were free to take the spoils of Wilson's labors without dealing with Wilson.    Despite hating this music scene, I recognize it is a great story of the independent do-it-yourself spirit as exhibited in the Tony Wilson character.
0793518326|5.0|The accuracy and authenticity of this collection is outstanding.  The collection is complete and will certainly help musicians re-create the Beatles' distinctive sound.  Different parts for other musical instruments are included as well as the vocals.  Tablature is also included.  This is a must have!<br /><br />Despite the complaints other reviews have made, I did not find that the print size was too small.  I also like the way the book showed which strings were being played on guitar for some of the chords for the music.<br /><br />Since NONE of the Beatles ever learned to read music, the inclusion of tabulature is most welcome.  Tabulature provides a \\"picture\\" of the guitar chord, the fret(s) and strings that are to be played.  It is an alternative method to reading music and is darned effective.  I can read music and I can read tabulature and am \\"bilingual\\" in that musical sense.  Providing both forms of musical language make this a much more inclusive work.<br /><br />If you want an outstanding, top notch book of Beatle songs with accuracy and good explanations, then you want this book.

However, she kept her views oblique and didn't try to explain anything explicitly.  She kept the proceedings mysterious and that is what novels about vampires need-a sense of mystery and the unexplainable.  Well, in this volume, Anne has the audacity (and this is not a good thing here) to unburden her views, through the voice of a character, the Devil, no less, on the mystery of life to the readers in minute details: the existence of God, the workings of heaven, the different castes of angels and supernatural beings, and even the creation of life itself is lovingly explained in dry textbook fashion.  So, Anne is a devout Catholic girl after all.  From the first few novels, I thought she might have some interesting, dare I say, heretic notion of god and religion.  Not so, it seems. B000001FS3|5.0|JT is my favorite U2 album for many reasons, but mostly because it sounds totally different every time I listen to it. Somehow the song I like least is \\"In God's Country\\" - maybe it is just TOO MUCH Edge going on... but it is still a better song than most other band's highlights. All this to say that JT is very enduring, very engaging and not a bit worn out. Bono has recently become something of a caricature of himself, but 18 years ago (!!!!) when JT came out he was hitting the stride that gave us two of the most visceral, emotional albums in rock... JT and Achtung Baby. U2 took the emotiveness of Bruce Springsteen and married it to a driving, thoroughly modern musical powertrip on JT... and it still sounds incredible.

B00070Q7VO|4.0|Apparently, a Boston cabbie sees and hears lots of things.  One night, picking up a fare outside the Wang Theater, some women (of varied ages) got in and announced that they were wearing no longer wearing their panties. The reason?  They had tossed them up on the stage adorned by Canadian sensation Michael Buble.<br /><br />I heard this story on a recent trip to Boston, where I also heard this CD.  Buble, I was told, is a dynamic and sexy singer, and he's got the everyman good looks and the stage moves (he's great with a microphone) to whip his public into a frenzy.  His repetoire reflects a penchant for standards, old and new, and some experimentation.  Buble is described sometimes as \\"middle of the road\\" and \\"smooth jazz,\\" but I think he's more  inventive and talented than those words imply to the jazz fan.  This is a guy whose grandfather encouraged him to listen to vocalists of the 1940's and 1950's, and on his better songs this tradition is evident.  His New York debut was in 2003 at the jazz-oriented Blue Note club, but he's been successful in more pop-oriented venues as well, notablyy in movies and TV.<br /><br />Buble's choice (and most singers probably wish they had this problem) is whether to lean more towards jazz or pop, or to stray towards some flashy jazz/pop commercial fusion that fails his early promise.  On his best songs his clear strong voice radiates superb phrasing and inventive dynamics--reigning in his vocal when you expect a punch (e.g., the dynamics on \\"You Don't Know Me By Now\\"). He gives a heartfelt performance on \\"A Foggy Day (in London Town),\\" and surprises with his rhythm and tone. Despite the frequent comparisons to Frank Sinatra and arranger Nelson Riddle, only \\"I've Got You Under My Skin\\" uses Riddle's score.  It's a tribute, not an impersonation.  He can sound like Sinatra at times, but it's not a slavish devotion. To me, the album's highlight is \\"The More I Want You,\\" he tells the story with believable emotion, not just relying on that freshly groomed voice.<br /><br />Yet, Buble clearly goes for some easy (some might say cheap) home runs, most notably on the undistinguished (except for the trumpet) \\"Song For You,\\" and the crowd pleasing \\"Latin\\" rhythms injected into \\"Save the Last Dance For Me.\\" There's also the obligatory duet, \\"Quando.\\"  The latter is pleasant enough, he and Furtado curve around each other's voices, but a listener won't develop a longterm romance with it. Similarly, on the opening \\"Feelin' Good,\\" he does a faithful reproduction of a brassy Las Vegas crowd pleaser, but its appeal is limited--you appreciate that he knows the tricks, but he's not adding much new.<br /><br />However, Buble's talent and musical savvy is just too deep, because he also hits you with interesting versions of \\"Can't Buy Me Love,\\" playing with the tempo, and \\"How Sweet It Is,\\" where his nicely messy voice mixes it up with some startlingly fresh blues guitar, harmonica, and organ. Although his one original number is somewhat disappointing, Buble's musicianship, originality, and appreciation of the total sound blow away most of his competition. He knows enough to let the instruments stand out, and his accompaniment is excellent, especially on bass and the trumpet and guitar solos. Overall, the youthful Mr. Buble has too much of a young man's voice; the timbre and shadings haven't had enough cooking time yet; however, this heartthrob has the potential for a longterm musical relationship, not just a one-night fling.oomed voice.    Yet, Buble clearly goes for some easy (some might say cheap) home runs, most notably on the undistinguished (except for the trumpet) \\"Song For You,\\" and the crowd pleasing \\"Latin\\" rhythms injected into \\"Save the Last Dance For Me.\\" There's also the obligatory duet, \\"Quando.\\"  The latter is pleasant enough, he and Furtado curve around each other's voices, but a listener won't develop a longterm romance with it. Similarly, on the opening \\"Feelin' Good,\\" he does a faithful reproduction of a brassy Las Vegas crowd pleaser, but its appeal is limited--you appreciate that he knows the tricks, but he's not adding much new.       However, Buble's talent and musical savvy is just too deep, because he also hits you with interesting versions of \\"Can't Buy Me Love,\\" playing with the tempo, and \\"How Sweet It Is,\\" where his nicely messy voice mixes it up with some startlingly fresh blues guitar, harmonica, and organ. Although his one original number is somewhat disappointing, Buble's musicianship, originality, and appreciation of the total sound blow away most of his competition. He knows enough to let the instruments stand out, and his accompaniment is excellent, especially on bass and the trumpet and guitar solos. Overall, the youthful Mr. Buble has too much of a young man's voice; the timbre and shadings haven't had enough cooking time yet; however, this heartthrob has the potential for a longterm musical relationship, not just a one-night fling.

'music of light.' oh, yes, mr. chris paltrow, you of the annoying pseudo-falsetto, three-day stubble, and impeccable bed-head hairdo(n't). you and mr. kinkade are marketer's dream! i can see the infomercials now: 'order today and get coldplay's new album 'x&y' with your purchase of any thomas kinkade print! the first fifty callers will also get a copy of gwenyth paltow's movie, 'sliding doors!'' (ok, that was actually a pretty good movie.)<br /><br />thomas kinkade and coldplay are just too good together not to market as one. both 'artists' are tailor-made for mass consumption (sell outs?) with their palatable and easily-digestable 'music' and 'art.' neither has an ounce of artistic cred. sorry, mr. paltrow fans, it's true.  i can see 'speed of sound'(though i liked it better the first time i heard it when it was called 'clocks') or 'what if' filtering through the windows of thomas kinkade's quaint little snowy hamlets while jill and jim walk up the driveway dressed in mittens and galoshes while a warm fire waits to warm their little hands.<br /><br />don't get me wrong -- i like coldplay. i do. (politik); but what is this heaping pile of burning crap you've unleashed upon us? did celine dion and meatloaf write your lyrics? did you and gwen invite them over to your flat one night and after some tea and crumpets sit down beside the fireplace and write this bunk? i'm wondering 'cos they've got all the depth of an inflatable kiddie pool in my aunt edna's backyard (just like ms. celine's and mr. meat's lyrics).<br /><br />sure the new album sounds pretty; but pretty doens't equal good. mr. paltrow, your songs have all the emotional punch of a wet noodle. i'm absolutely dumbfounded 'Q' call this drivel a 'masterpiece,' check out the aforementioned bands if you want to hear some music that'll blow your mind (did someone really call jason mraz's album a 'masterpiece' on this here amazon.com?!?!).<br /><br />mr. paltrow -- you've got the talent. stop writing songs in hopes of raising shareholder stock prices.  stop going for the loud/soft vocal dynamic on EVERY song. we know you can go all falsetto on us. believe us, we know. both my ears know. lock yourselves in some old, haunted castle, don't eat for days, divorce gwen, maybe drop some e or something, then write some songs. in the words of brett anderson,'get your demon back' (assuming you had a demon to begin with.)<br /><br />for me, putting 'x&y' in the stereo was like hoping for a nice bite into a chocolate truffle ('cos they've got the chops, only the knives are dull), only to realize you've got a mouth full of air-puffed breakfast cereal. no es frio.<br /><br />we must unite and stop the madness now B00007LTIC|5.0|This is an excellent album!  Many here have given very intelligent reviews of this wonderful work, but I thought I would add my voice to those proclaiming this a valuable piece of prog-rock history.  The opening track 'Going for the One' hits pretty strongly right out of the gate, although a bit raucous at times, it still conveys a positive message through its lyrics.  Parallels is another favorite, I heard the live version of this song long before the studio version, and let me say that the studio version is superior, the addition of the church organ adds the missing element, Wakeman just plain rocks!  Wonderous Stories is a classic, and Awaken is purely outstanding, and my favorite track off the album.  It moves from more rocking segments 'Gentle, Mass, Touch' to the light airy passages, to the powerful conclusion.  I would agree with those who've said this may not make a good 'First' Yes album.  Close to the Edge gets that vote, but this one is definitely not to be missed.  A great album!  Outstanding!
B0002O0CM0|5.0|I remember reading some reviews for other Doors CDs a while back, and one of them made a reference to these two albums that the Doors recorded after the death of lead singer Jim Morrison.  So I was naturally curious to see what that would sound like.  I bought the CD expecting to be let down, but after listening to it I feel just the opposite emotion.  The other three can do just fine on their own, with songs like \\"In The Eye of the Sun\\" and \\"Variety is the Spice of Life.\\"  My attitude toward this CD is similar to my attitude toward the Who continuing to tour with two of their members missing.  No it will never be the same, but that in no way means it's bad.
B000002ITM|5.0|I was given this album a couple of years ago (in 2001) and at first I only really listened to a few tracks. I didn't really appreciate Testament at first, but after some time and maturing in my \\"Metal Ear,\\" I really got into these guys; and man is \\"The Ritual\\" a brilliant CD...<br /><br />Although recorded in 1992, this album has a strongly classical 80's Metal sound. The production is very good and well produced, but not overproduced. The production creates a wonderful synthesis of sound that really allows all the instruments and vocals to be heard clearly and no single element overpowers another except when needed i.e solos. Speaking of solos, Hot Damn! Some solos on this album like on \\"So Many Lies,\\" are so enthralling and ghostly as a sound sample of a priest preaches under the piercing guitar solo. The riff on this song is also really impressive and carries the song along its dark path. \\"Agony,\\" was one of the very first songs I immediately loved on this album. Fast but not too fast, this song kicks some serious ass! The lyrics totally rip and the instruments play in perfect unison.<br /><br />Altogether the album is a really solid, strong offering from Testament. Some songs are much slower and paced like \\"The Ritual,\\" (the song, not the album) which is dark, haunting and foreboding and echoes all the traits of true classical Metal. \\"Return To Serenity,\\" is also a much slower song that seems alot sadder and introspective, but still has killer riffs and beautiful, resonating guitar parts. The vocals are also deep and penetrating, and the drums keep the overall rhythm and feeling of the song through a rather simple yet effective beat. This album offers quite alot of diversity and covers a number of topics like religious beliefs, pain, sadness, loneliness and life after death.<br /><br />What keeps this album so interesting is the various paces, effects used (i.e a flanger with distortion is used in \\"The Sermon,\\" which brings waves of tension and anxiety to the song) and extensive topics covered by the band. In fact, \\"The Ritual,\\" is far from ritualistic and offers a fresh, unique topic on every single track. The guitar sounds are tight and well created, the drums pound, keep rhythm and guide the songs and the lyrics growl, move and keep you interested.<br /><br />\\"The Ritual,\\" is a fantastic, amazing and impressive album. I strongly recommend it for fans of classic Heavy Metal as well as newer Metallers. If you enjoy diversity, complexity, pain, anguish, sadness and beauty, \\"The Ritual,\\" will definitely keep you entertained and enthralled...covered by the band. In fact, \\"The Ritual,\\" is far from ritualistic and offers a fresh, unique topic on every single track. The guitar sounds are tight and well created, the drums pound, keep rhythm and guide the songs and the lyrics growl, move and keep you interested.    \\"The Ritual,\\" is a fantastic, amazing and impressive album. I strongly recommend it for fans of classic Heavy Metal as well as newer Metallers. If you enjoy diversity, complexity, pain, anguish, sadness and beauty, \\"The Ritual,\\" will definitely keep you entertained and enthralled...
B0009I7NNA|5.0|I really can't understand how anyone can say Avenged Sevenfold is done. While I am a big fan of today's metal and classic, I have to admit I'm drawn more to the retro rock (and I'm only 18, so it's not just me longing for the old days). A7X has always been great at blending modern and classic metal, and this CD proves it.<br /><br />I have to admit that the first time I listened to City Of Evil, I really couldn't wait for it to be over so I could go back to listening to Waking The Fallen. But after a second play-through, I realized that the music on this CD is amazing. Strength Of The World has to be the best A7X song I have heard (except for I Won't See You Tonight Part 1, of course), and yes kiddies, I have all three CDs. The Wicked End has the best orchestral interlude of any metal/orchestra blend that I've heard.<br /><br />While initially disappointed by the fact that there is no screaming except in the beginning of a couple songs, I came to realize that it only allows Shadows to be even more emotionally involved in his singing.<br /><br />All in all, Avenged Sevenfold still has it goin' on. All three CDs have shown their endless supply of talent, each in different ways. And I commend them for not caring what the closed minds and critics would think about this album.

In fact, it may have surpassed the prequel. <br /> <br />Something Blue picks up where Something Borrowed left off. Darcy has discovered her best friend and her fiance together, and storms off in a huff. When her relationship with her ex-fiance's roommate peters out, she finds herself pregnant and alone, with no real friends. <br /> <br />Determined to make a fresh start, Darcy cajoles Ethan (her fifth-grade boyfriend) into letting her stay with him in London. He is reluctant, but agrees. <br /> <br />What follows is a personal journey, bumpy and engaging, as Darcy evolves from an extremely self-centered person into someone who can take part in a real relationship. The book, like its predecessor, is deeper than the pink and blue covers imply. <br /> <br />Strongly recommended.
