B00070DK14|3.0|I've seen all the very positive reviews for this album and I'm afraid I'm going to have to be in the minority when I say that I'm not terribly fond of this album and think that it's a bit overrated, especially by Ian Anderson himself. I really liked the previous album, \\" A \\". Yes, it was somewhat of a departure from the traditional Jethro Tull sound, but I thought it was an exciting and dynamic departure and very welcome, in my opinion. Very heavy and progressive and electronic. I also thought it was cool that Eddie Jobson was in the group, especially since I was a big U.K. fan.<br /><br />So what happened on \\" Broadsword and the Beast \\"? Looks like Anderson and company tried to both take a step back and take a step forward at the same time and other than four tracks that I really love, I would say it did not work.<br /><br />Broadsword certainly SOUNDS more like a traditional Tull album than \\" A \\", with the return of more rustic and acoustic instruments like mandolin and a bit more acoustic guitar and flute. This is probably due to the fact that the songs on Broadsword were written for a Jethro Tull album, while the tracks for \\" A \\" were written for a possible Ian Anderson solo album. Anderson had let his hair grow back ( and how!), so he was looking more like his younger self. Broadsword, with it's cartoon front and back cover, certainly LOOKS more like a traditional Tull album, too. And, alas, these are some of my problems with the album. I almost feel Tull became caricature's of themselves on this, CARTOON caricatures, in reference to the cover. I think they should have either stuck with the progressive, electronic rock of  \\" A \\", or gone back to a more traditional hard rock sound.<br /><br />My other main gripe? The songs themselves. Of the ten songs found on the original album, I only liked ( or loved) four of them. Those songs include the opening track, \\" Beastie \\", which has some very dangerous sounding synthesizers at the beginning and great lyrics and singing from Anderson. My favorite song is \\" Slow Marching Band \\", which was the last in a trio of wonderful, heartfelt ballads from Anderson, which began with \\" Home \\" from Stormwatch and continued with \\" And Further On \\" from A. I particularly love the refrain for  \\" Slow Marching Band \\". It also showed that while Anderson's voice was getting a bit weaker and more stratchy, he could still sing them acoustic guitar songs and the ballads. My only gripe about this wonderful sad, melodic song is the cliched drum entrance on the bridge. \\" Broadsword \\", which may be the heaviest tune on the album (or maybe not) is also quite enjoyable, with it's slight Indian style drum beat and them beautiful sounding synthesizers. I also really like \\" Seal Driver \\" for some reason. It rocks out a bit, gets a bit jazzy in the middle, probably one of the more tuneful and at the same time most progressive numbers on the album.<br /><br />I really don't care for the other six songs on this, unfortunately. As a an anti-matter of fact (or fiction), this was the first Tull album since either Songs From The Wood or Too Old To Rock-n-Roll that contained a song or two that I outright HATE! The song on Broadsword that gets that vote is \\" Watching Me Watching You \\". It's a stupid, little electronic piece with some ridiculous lyrics and even more ridiculous singing. IT'S RIDICULOUS, I TELL YOU! With it's heavy reliance on drum machines and synthesizers, it was also an indication of the musical path Tull would follow on their next album. And \\" Cheerio \\"....what a weak, closing track. At least it's the shortest song here.<br /><br /> I must say that I DO like the sound of the synthesizers and I like the fact that guitarist Martin Barre is heard from more on this. And I DO like the front and back cover, by the way.<br /><br />The remastered version comes with two pages of liner notes from Ian Anderson and eight bonus tracks. Contrary to what it says on the CD wrap, these eight songs are not ' previouslyunreleased ' ; they stopped being previously unreleased when they first appeared on the 20 Years Of Jethro Tull Boxed Set back in 1988. Nevertheless, their inclusion here makes perfect sense, since they were recorded during the sessions for Broadsword. While none of these eight songs are not that bad ( I actually think they are better than some of the songs that originally MADE the album), they are nothing very special, either. Perhaps they catch on after a few listens.<br /><br />So, as I said in the opening paragraph, I guess I'm in the minority here in my opinion of the album, which nonetheless I'm sure will appeal to some Tull fans.nreleased when they first appeared on the 20 Years Of Jethro Tull Boxed Set back in 1988. Nevertheless, their inclusion here makes perfect sense, since they were recorded during the sessions for Broadsword. While none of these eight songs are not that bad ( I actually think they are better than some of the songs that originally MADE the album), they are nothing very special, either. Perhaps they catch on after a few listens.    So, as I said in the opening paragraph, I guess I'm in the minority here in my opinion of the album, which nonetheless I'm sure will appeal to some Tull fans.
B0006V6TMG|1.0|If you are a Jesse Cook fan, this is a fun cd - it makes you want to see the video.  For strictly music, i'd choose another of his cd's without the \\"live\\" sound effects
B00000IGGA|5.0|\\"Down by the Riverside motel  It's 10 below and falling  By a 99 cent store  She closed her eyes and started swaying  But it's so hard to dance that way  When it's cold and there's no music  Well your old hometown's so far away  But inside your head there's a record that's playing  A song called 'hold on'...\\"    -from Hold On    A heartbreaking verse, made all the more touching by the fact that Tom Waits' own daughter actually inspired the lines \\"but it's so hard to dance that way/when it's cold and there's no music.\\" She said something to this effect after observing somebody really doing this on a street corner.    So it seems appropriate that Mule Variations has traces of warmth and family all over it. The sad lament of House Where Nobody Lives. The dusty, tired reflections of Pony. The tender crooning on Picture in a Frame. The bittersweet ruminations in Georgia Lee. The unbelievable sweetness that makes up Take it with Me and the reassuring phrases of Come on Up to the House. Waits and his co-writer/wife Kathleen Brennan fashion exquisite tales of loneliness, loss, redemption, and deep love.     In addition to doing that well, they can also turn out stuff that's all dirty and bluesy (Get Behind the Mule, Cold Water) funny and clever (Big in Japan, Chocolate Jesus), downright odd (Lowside of the Road, Eyeball Kid), or dream-like and totally eerie (Black Market Baby).  What's He Building? and Filipino Box Spring Hog were penned by Waits alone - the former being a cryptic, clanging spoken-word poem and the latter being just completely outrageous (did the title give it away?) And of course, the voice. Whether it be a low, scratchy growl or insane, crazed shouting, the singing fluctuates wildly from song to song.    It's a schizophrenic collection (the sequence is strange and great - an abundance of stomp and noise is immediately followed by a soft ballad), dominated by piano, guitar, percussion, harmonica, sax, trumpet, even turntables. The musicians are fantastic (Marc Ribot, Greg Cohen, Ralph Carney, Smokey Hormel, Les Claypool, Charlie Musselwhite, Larry Taylor, John Hammond, etc). The album has a weary, \\"home-y\\" feel to it; wise and vulnerable and very, very endearing. Tom is amazing and Mule Variations is plain beautiful!
B000002GYN|4.0|In 1972 Glenn Frey and Don Henley's band The Eagles released their debut album, simply self-titled, The Eagles. While the bands debut may not have legendary status as some of their feature albums do or the great claim that other debut albums by Led Zeppelin and Aerosmith have but this isnt a bad album either! No I dont pull out this one and listen to it as much as I do One Of These Nights or The Long Run, but this is still a good listen every once in a while.<br /><br />The album features some of the bands biggest and best hits, The Jackson Brown co-written gem 'Take It Easy' apears here, the slower 'Peaceful Easy Fellin' also arose on this album, as well as the rocker 'Whitchy Woman' which I think is one of the bands all time best songs.<br /><br />But this is a album of more then just a few hit singles. With 'Take It Easy' opening the album and 'Whitchy Woman' following your set for a great album, or so you'd think. 'Chug All Night' while very catchy and a decent song, can get old and worn out after a while. While The Eagles usualy made beautiful ballads on this album they obvously hadnt found thei nitch as ballader's. 'Most Of Us Are Sad' is a decent ballad but nothing like the band was capable of. 'Nightingale' is a good little rocker featuring that signature harmonic vocals we came to love from the band, while 'Train Leaves Here This Morning' is a nice little country flavored song bidding farewell to a lover. Next is what has to be my favorite song on the album, 'Take The Devil.' It is  simply one of the best songs the band has ever written and recorded! The whole general feel of the songs is amazing, and everything I love about this band can be sumed up in 'Take The Devil!' 'Early Bird' is another little country-rocker with good guitar and selfreflective lyrics. 'Peaceful Easy Feeling' was never one of my favorite Eagles songs but on a hot summer day it can be the perfect song! The album ends with 'Tryin' which is a cool song to end the album with and really the best song to have ended the album, they song leaves you wanting more and was a sign of things to come from the band.<br /><br />All in all this is a pretty good album, not classic or essential by any means but still good. Glen Frey and Don Henleys song written and vocals are great here. But what has always been my favorite thing about The Eagles is the guitar playing, the band has always featured great guitar playing, and it's not in short supply. So to all country fans, I would recomend this album, as well as to all Eagles fans, Casual or Diehard. I would also recomend this album to all guitar players or fans of.ly the best song to have ended the album, they song leaves you wanting more and was a sign of things to come from the band. <br /> <br />All in all this is a pretty good album, not classic or essential by any means but still good. B00092ZL80|5.0|During the EWF set, Philip Bailey asks the audience how many have been with them for the 30 years they've been around. Well, I was into them before then, back when pretty much only R&B or FM college stations played them, and later on watching Verdine 'levitate' onstage, so I guess I've seen and heard enough of them to know that they aren't fakin' the funk 30+ years later. <br /> <br />Also, thanks to an extremely hip, musically adventurous young deejay on Detroit R&B radio in the late '60s/early '70s (Donnie Simpson, who went on to become instrumental in the formation of BET), I became an avid fan of Chicago's early music. The arrangements and the horns just blew me away, and Robert Lamm could sing to me anytime he wanted to.  <br /> <br />Putting these two bands together on the tour stage was a stroke of genius. While both individual sets were very good (the music was extremely tight, the instrumental solos were killer, especially Walt Parazaider's flute on \\"Just You and Me,\\" and the vocals were, for the most part, on track (some age was showing -- but isn't that to be expected?). Robert Lamm is STILL in great voice, and Philip's range is still quite remarkable. As a diehard EWF fan, I selfishly would have liked more of their lesser known hits included, but I realize that this was a joint concert. <br /> <br />The opening and the finale, however, are worth the price of either the live ticket or the DVD. In the finale, six amazing songs (\\"September,\\" \\"Free,\\" \\"Singasong,\\" \\"Does Anybody Really Know What Time It Is,\\" \\"Shining Star,\\" and \\"25 or 6 to 4\\") seamlessly woven in one right after the other, with the only real break in music being after \\"Shining Star,\\" as the crowd is screaming for more. They aren't disappointed... \\"25 or 6 to 4\\" totally rocks the entire house! You would think these guys had played this music together for decades. They did not play as two awesome bands, but as one band that NOBODY could touch! They seem to really feed off of one another, and looked like they loved every second of it! <br /> <br />My kids range in age from 21 to 4, and they play this DVD as much as I do!

B0001GH7KY|4.0|House By The Cemetery is another fine film that is often missed among horror lovers. While it's not a masterpiece, it is a very satisfying killer flick.<br /><br />Trimming down the movie's plot to it's essentials, HBTC presents the story of the horrifying legend of a man, Dr. Freudstein, who has been living in the basement of a creepy house for many years -- surviving off of the cells of living humans he captures. The Boyle family, who've just moved into the house, are the most recent unlucky bunch to meet the zombie Doctor and face his diabolical intentions. Will they escape? Or will they just become a few more bodies in Freudstein's mass grave of a laboratory?<br /><br />Fulci attempts to throw in a little \\"twist\\" for the ending, and I suppose he succeeds, even though I, for one, was a little confused by the ending. It seems interesting, but the meaning of it is not too clear. Nonetheless, you can be assured that even if you miss any underlying cleverness, you should still be able to enjoy this good old-fashioned piece of horror. The only complaint I have is of the english overdubs. I warn you: the vocal actors are horrible. But hopefully you can ignore it and only use it as hate for the victims. Mwahahahaha...

There's familiar strains coming through from previous works - as everybody as pointed out - the piano-tinkling of The Fragile puts in an appearance at the end, for example. But Only, for example, is something new to NIN. It's pretty much unabashed disco, and the closest we've ever seen to that was something from the PHM era. It's also the first spoken word-ish thing since Down In It, which wasn't a shining star in Reznor's song library. <br />I have to dock points simply because WT hasn't got the same perfectionist skill as Reznor's previous releases. 0671004107|3.0|This book has good ideas and characters as well as a nuanced story, but for some reason I just didn't think it was all that good.  I liked Ellie, the chief protagonist, who was psychologically complex and a striver for discovery - she had a funny relationship with her father and step father, which influenced her ability to get close to men, perhaps focusing her on the search for intelligent life.  Of course, she makes a great discovery and then fights the bureaucracy to get a chance to travel to the new beings with the technology that they transmit.  Then of course there is the journey and the disappointing reactions of mankind, etc.  THis is a solid and believable plot.<br /><br />That is fine so far as it goes.  Somehow, it just felt static to me, rather than pulsing with the life that a novel by Octavia Butler or even Frank Herbert does.  Perhaps it is because I regard the best hard scifi as genuinely great novels that I found this so mediocre.  The characters are more vehicles for ideas than living beings, perhaps, or they just weren't all that interesting outside of their amazing adventure.<br /><br />Tepidly recommended.  Go elsewhere for great hard scifi.
